40797764.review:
Well... This game was definitely introduces a new concept to the gaming. But it has its pros and cons with this new implementations of this concept:

+ Rich and detailed worlds that a structural analyst would die for!
+ I loved how you can work like an engineer to fix stuff!
+ Deep story with environmental storytelling
+ Based on Source
+ Good graphics for its engine. Not the best but still good.
+ Great community.
+ This was one of those games that I felt like I live in its world.

Before getting to the cons I'd like to say that I am a completionist. So the cons will be from the perspective of completionism.

- Collectibles were awful. There were too many of them and were hard to count especially because of the lack of an inventory system.
- Developers LOVES to change the locations of collectibles with constant updates for no reason. I use guides a lot in games and these kind of updates instantly makes those guides I use obselete! I had so many troubles counting, calculating and looking for the data of collectibles. I am currently stuck at Part 3 and its "corruption documents" collectible. I will probably never have the will to attempt %100 this game.
- Stairs... STAIRS WERE SO BAD! They were the worst stairs I have ever seen in a Source engine game. They destroyed the sense of environmental navigation for me.
- Some areas are too dark, some are too bright.
- The batteries of the camera and the flashlight were probably produced by the cavemen with some sticks and flint taped together with a maple leaf. They deplete so quickly! At least they were kinda easy to find.

Still though. I will recommend this game if you don't mind %100 it. I kinda have a gaming OCD. :D So I did and I am regretting my decision. But if you are unlike me, you will have a lot of fun exploring the old structures, fixing the broken machinery and even solving a corporate corruption mystery! Have fun!

40520051.review:
I wanted to like this game. I really did. I was really intrigued by the novel concept of the game. I sunk 16 hours into it, but in the end I couldn't bring myself to keep going with it. Some people have pointed out issues with some of the game mechanics, or the annoying flashlight and camera with the worst battery life in the world. But my biggest criticism of the game is its absolutely, glacially slow pace.

To be honest, after 16 hours, I'm still not sure if the game actually HAS a story. I got to Chapter 6 of 11, which gets past the first Act and into Act 2. But throughout the whole time, I was waiting for this "fight for survival" that the game description mentions. That never happens. Or at least, it never happens after 16 hours of gameplay. The game doesn't have a story, it has hints of a story, some bits and pieces you encounter throughout your exploration, of some story of corruption that happened thirty years ago. I kept waiting for something more to come of that. But all I got was scatter notes, the occasional audio recording, and....lots of wandering through buildings relatively aimlessly. Either that means there really IS no story to this game...or else it has a pretty serious problem with pacing. Take your pick.

That said, there are some things that this game does phenomenally well. The buildings and world you inhabit are incredibly detailed, with lots of those gray boxes and electrical panels that you probably walk by every day without paying any attention to. The nature of the game forces you to consider your surroundings, and there is lots of rich detail in those surroundings to keep you focused. The developers also added lots of neat little easter eggs and hidden content that is fun to stumble across. The puzzles feel very natural to the theme of the game, and in general I found them very well done. Some puzzles are necessary to progress in the game; others are optional. But mostly they involve getting machinery working properly -- getting a water purification plant up and running, getting a forklift operational, etc. That doesn't sound thrilling, but it's rewarding to find the correct process.

Ultimately, I can't say I recommend this game, but there are some people (clearly, from the other reviews here) to whom this game will appeal. If you are a fan of exploration, walking simulators, and environmental puzzles, you may really like this game! All I can say is, be prepared to make your own story, or come up with your own purpose for continuing on, because there is very little in terms of story or plot to sustain you. Or there was little to sustain me, at any rate. I've put in a hard day's work as a structural analyst, but in the end I'm not sure it's a career move I was really willing to make.

40354017.review:
This is a game that fails at giving a good first impression. The graphics look a bit outdated, especially at first, like they are from 10 years ago. Models are a bit simplistic (especially human models), voice acting is not exactly stellar, animations are not exactly brilliant, the premise and story feel uninteresting and boring, and some of the interactive elements and controls feel a bit clunky.

But this is highly deceptive. The more you advance in this game, the more and more interesting and enticing it becomes. This is a relatively long game, with not much action going on, but it still manages to keep you incredibly captivated. You just have to explore every corner and every cranny, and you just have to check if there's a way to open that one door, or that one floodgate, or reach that one platform, and see what's on the other side... And the story, which felt so uninteresting at first, starts becoming more and more intriguing. The game is full of exploration and discovery, done in a surprisingly interesting manner.

I got completely hooked, and just had to play the game to the end. When I play this game, I get the strong feeling that the developers enjoyed making this game as much as I enjoy playing it. This just feels like a labor of love.

39919229.review:
Один из лучших симуляторов ходьбы, а главное очень атмосферный и вот почему:

Превосходная детализация окружения и проработка уровней. По сюжету, вооружившись каской, фонариком, камерой и дозой сарказма, мы исследуем локации на наличие возможных разрушений и решаем головоломки. Попытки взглянуть за каждый угол, внезапно увеличивают размеры местности и порой кажется, что пройти игру можно и с другой стороны, и не всегда самой явной. Ещё раз хочу выделить атмосферу игры; сразу видно, что разработчик подошёл с душой и это действительно так. Проект очень масштабный и 47 часов игры тому доказательство. Иногда мозг просто вскипает от количества вариантов пройти ту или иную местность, решить или забить на головоломку и пройти дальше. Количество чтива в виде документов, писем просто зашкаливает. Хотя есть один минус - отсутствие возможности читать их на русском языке. Главный герой тоже не из молчаливых и довольно интересно с юмором коментирует некоторые ситуации или же сами диалоги с другими персонажами. 

Ставлю 10/10 закрученых вентилей на трубах.

39723803.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Too long has passed since a video game was worthy of my “Wait, there’s more?!?” custom achievement and recognition. In fact, 2009’s Wolfenstein (shamefully  and inexplicably withdrawn from Steam and other digital distribution platforms) was among the last that comes to mind. Allow me to explain. Nearly two decades of gaming experience have taught me to estimate quite precisely, what to expect from a title in terms of both length and content. INFRA is a welcome exception from my unwritten rule. Even more surprising, it’s the Steam debut for developer Loiste Interactive which also acted as publishers  for their first project. Calling it a labour of love, is an understatement. Initially released as a three-part story since early 2016, the past two years have seen INFRA finally releasing as a unified game.

[h1]Story[/h1]
“INFRA” is referring to “infrastructure” most likely, yet the underlying tones hint at another kind of road network. One which has nothing to do with going places, but rather opening doors which were never meant to be accessed. Enough metaphors though. The game shall feature corruption in its material form so to speak, since the fictional city of Stalburg is literally crumbling under the weight of negligence and incompetence fuelled by one person’s desires to enrich himself and control as many destinies as he can. Before I’ll discuss the antagonist though, let’s focus on INFRA’s protagonist. Structural engineer Mark is tasked by his company (NCG – National Consulting Group) to survey a few key locations within Stalburg and coordinate the necessary maintenance as the situation shall demand it. Unlike Gordon Freeman, Mark’s only weapons are his keen sight (assisted by a trusty digital camera) and sharp wit. Also the obligatory flashlight, naturally. But no weapons at all. There are no enemies to harass players and you have no reason to shoot back at something.

It will not be easy at all and Mark will have to fight for his survival, yet he’ll be facing natural or man-made obstacles, not conventional foes. The main culprit in Stalburg’s current state is an industry magnate which doesn’t take “no” for an answer. Jeff Walter is a man that knows just how far you can get if you’ve got local authorities and politicians in your back pocket. He’ll not be stopped by his business rivals since he’s always managed to be one step ahead of them and even run their affairs into the ground, buying them once they’re close to bankruptcy and “finishing the job” himself. It all seems legal on the surface but the city and its inhabitants are slowly starting to react and fight back. Within this backdrop of uncertainty, poverty and acrimony, Mark must fulfill his duties and care for structures and industries whose employees have seemingly abandoned in disrepair.

Central themes for this title include: urban and industrial decay (Metro/S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series), mechanical, electrical and environmental puzzles (TARTARUS/Portal series) and a cult of personality matching Bioshock’s Andrew Ryan to INFRA’s Jeff Walter. It’s important to notice that while I could find certain stylistic similarities with the aforementioned games, INFRA is an entirely original story, with its own well-documented albeit fictional locations and characters. And there isn’t a combat section at all. How well documented? We’re literally talking about hundreds of documents and points of interest. I’m honestly surprised by the attention to detail in nearly all regards. There are so many handwritten notes alone, which must have taken quite a lot to simply plan, not to mention insert in the countless rooms Mark shall be visiting. And they make sense since they all point towards one inevitable conclusion.

Piece by piece, the evidence gathered against Walter will begin to form a clear picture for Mark and all his associates to see. Taking pictures of the damage sustained by the surveyed locations, is only half the mission since our protagonist seems licensed in investigative journalism besides his engineering degree. Makes sense though, for the firm which was hired to make repairs, to also find out how did it come to this dire situation in the first place. The answer is Stalburg’s rampant corruption on all levels. Someone has to pay and Mark will make sure of that. In his own nonviolent way, of course. That’s a big part of INFRA’s appeal to me. Just like playing Dishonored without killing anyone, for example, not all conflicts must be resolved through bloodshed and I’m glad that some video games offer this option and break from the norm.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
As a die hard fan of Dear Esther and Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines, I knew INFRA was powered by the Source Engine within less than 5 minutes of playing it. I have to agree that while some age-related limitations are becoming obvious (such as the lack of truly large, open level implementation), Loiste Interactive are also skilled artists, not just storytellers. Very few textures might give away the graphical engine’s “ancient” age and most visual assets are an excellent match to what Unity Engine can also achieve. And both Source and Unity are guaranteeing stability to my system, even when running their projects maxed out and on 4K resolution. 

Just how much did I like what I saw and played in INFRA? Enough to capture over 200 screenshots (and counting) while publishing a majority of them on my Steam profile as well. INFRA is a rare case in which you’ll appreciate both its looks and the messages it sends. So far, I’ve met no glitches, crashes or even frame rate drops in this game’s case. I really can’t complain even if I wanted to. As for sheer location variety, I’ll got further into detail in the gameplay section. Suffice to say, there’s not a dull moment in sight and most locations distance themselves from the previously visited places.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
Since it’s usually sporting a more relaxed perspective than the combat-heavy titles I compared some if its themes, INFRA tends to showcase this in its soundtrack and laid-back voice acting. Mark’s a true professional and he rarely loses his composure, even after his boss sends him from one “suicide mission” to another. Stalburg’s slowly falling apart but here’s one structural engineer who’s doing his best to contain the damage and even repair what can still be recovered. Sound effects are well represented, so I also couldn’t find any apparent flaws in the audio assets. A quality title clearly proud of its production values, through and through.

[h1]Gameplay, Verdict, Summary & Rating are below in the Comment Section.[/h1]

39612121.review: This game is a major crap shoot, so be careful before spending the money. 39543251.review:
This game is the best I've ever played to date. I'm not one to have many games but this tops all of the ones I have. 

At face value it seems to be a simple game where you picture all structural faults and technical documents and navigate through long forgotten infrastructure, but soon you are enveloped into a story where the people whom you meet through old documents and tape recorders, and even your own coworkers, are not who you once thought them to be. You find out deep rooted schemes of the past, political rigging, manipulation of influential figures and secret sinister projects which were hushed up: all as you navigate through abandoned buildings, tunnels, and as you escape to your office when disaster for the entire city could happen if you, the player, don't think quickly and do the right things.

As you navigate through all these buildings and old hash-ups which seem to try and kill you, the game poses the question to you: Do you want to reveal the problems with the city of Stalburg and ensure security for its inhabitants, or, do you want to save your life above everything else?

Because of this, the game will end in different ways taylored to your attitudes to what is around you and how you deal with it. That's the beauty of this game in my opinion. It's so pleasingly simple but at the same time the storyline which you are led into is entirely separate. It's fun and yet again mind blowing with the attention to detail to all the textures and themes it brings. The [ageing gracefully] Source Engine has been used to the full in this game and it's the best I've seen from it to date.

Even the tools you have at your disposal is enticing. All you have is a torch, a camera around your neck and the wits about you. I don't know if it is just me but I really enjoy the use of a camera in-game. It's just pleasing.

Same must be said for the soundtrack. Never heard of Finnian Langham before but his music for this game is fantastic. Even for a musical brain like me this soundtrack is amazing. Having the DLC was a good purchase for me as the music is really good. I can't speak highly enough.

It is sad to see that this game is finished. Every part came with new excitement, packed with new stories and closure, even if we had to wait for months at a time. It was so enjoyable I wish it would never end... maybe it hasn't ended! (Dream on!)

Recommending it to people with an eye for a story and those like to hear a Finnish person comment on structural defects that you photograph. "That's not good."

39517926.review:
So, up-front, when I bought this game I thought it was going to be more of a straight puzzle/investigation game.

So in the event that you are under that impression; it's not that.

If you ever played Half-Life and really liked how that game spent a lot of time in the guts of the facility, climbing around in vents and service tunnels, and solving environmental problems - then you know what this game is like. It's that, only with all of its attention spent on that aspect, without enemies to fight. Which if you're me, is actually good thing.

The level design is great (there are a few areas that dragged on a bit for being visually repetitive), and the puzzles it introduces are challenging without (usually) being so obscure that you need to seek a walkthrough. I got stuck in a couple of places due to it not being clear what the game wanted me to do, but in general trial and error was enough to progress.

The voice acting of the protagonist is pretty wonky - the guy has a good voice but the delivery is always borderline confused, like he genuinely doesn't know what he's saying. Every other voice in the game is pretty decent, so it's weird that the one that's so front-and-center is so awkward. But it wasn't anything that killed it for me, it was just a weird quirk.

Anyway, the game ended up being a lot longer than I expected, and I enjoyed the vast majority of my time with it. I'd definitely recommend it if you like this kind of environmental exploration/problem solving, and aren't going to care about the absence of enemies to fight.

39484250.review:
A great composition of puzzles, exploration, and some action. The constant rewards for not taking the direct route are nice, and plenty of intriguing secrets are spread all over for you to discover.
You are even given the option of ignoring most of the puzzles if you choose, with clearly marked exits that don't require you to completely solve an area before moving on.

The game firmly believes in rewarding you for going beyond though, with actions you take in the very first areas having repercussions all the way towards the way. Be ready to play through this game multiple times if you want to see all there is to see, and make sure to stock up on some logic because you'll undoubtedly spend time on various puzzles throughout if you want them solved optimally.

39455755.review: Однозначно 5. Я б поставил спор между Portal 2 и INFRA

39374771.review:
INFRA is an experience that you don't want to miss out on. While I was on the fence about getting the game, I quickly realized that it is well worth the money. By the end of the first chapter, there was no way I could stop playing: the story line isn't cinema worthy but it is truly captivating.

Gameplay is simple yet versatile. You have a flashlight and a camera and are sent off to explore the labyrinth that is Stalburg. The voice acting is quite terrible but once you get past the initial cringe-iness, the voice acting is much more humorous. You can play the game at any pace: speedrun where your only objective is to get to the end; engineer, where your due diligence and ability to notice any and all minutae in your surroundings pays off with the satisfaction that you've made progress; it's your choice.

The balance between an amount of physical inaccessibility guiding you -- be it through locked doors, welded portals, or passages to what seems like nowhere -- and the amount of autonomy given to you, pushing you to explore anything and everything is truly mastered in the game. Whereas some games push you along by inhibiting your extraneous paths, INFRA provides a natural number of potential paths leading to different stories, outcomes, and realms. You're not overwhelmed by an inordinate amount of free choice whereby taking a path of your choice leads to your demise; rather your ability to take the path that you find rewarding proves itself in what you find.

INFRA is certainly not a game to be taken for granted. Nor is it to be played only once. The number of times I went left instead of right; up instead of down; or forwards instead of backwards begs my curiousity to revisit it.

The environment is magnificent; 6 GB of scenery (and mechanics, critical game files, etc.) shows itself realistically, smoothly, immersively, and beautifully. The sounds are well placed and immersion in the game is almost instant.

That's not to say there is nothing wrong with this game. Some gameplay mechanics could be improved, functionality could be tweaked as far as interactive objects are concerned, and some graphic effects could be augmented.

In any case, if you are on the fence about buying the game, for me the game is well worth the price. I don't know any other game like INFRA and which perform at or above its level. I will be definitely giving the game more hours played.

39161114.review:
TL;DR is at the bottom.

Where to start with this game...It is an extremely immersive first-person adventure/puzzler.  All you have to your name is a flashlight and a camera.  You start as a structural inspector but quickly turn into an engineer extraodinair while traversing a dam, steel plant, water treatment plant, and so on. There are lots of rewarding feelings you will get when playing this game as some of the puzzles are very challenging and it's a story I won't soon forget.  It's fun to explore around, read notes, listen to tape recordings and follow the story of Stalburg and it's people.  However, the game doesn't come without its drawbacks.

First and foremost: DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME UNLESS YOU ARE READY TO INVEST SOME SERIOUS TIME IN BEATING JUST THE MAIN STORY.  This is probably the  longest linear/semi-linear story game I have ever played and that's saying something because this is a cheap indie game running on source engine. My main complaint is that this game was just too long.  I realize this sounds like an odd complaint and that most people want plenty of bang for their buck, but I clocked nearly 22 hours just gunning through the main story.  There are puzzles to complete when running through the main story but there are also lots of auxilary puzzles that can be completed on the side but in the true indie game fashion - there is no hud, no written objectives, and nothing to tell you when you're on a side objective or the main objective.  So it took me up until about 15 hours into the game before I started to be able to pick out what to look for in puzzles to determine if it was main story or otherwise.

TL;DR
Pros:
-Very immersive
-Good graphics/source engine reliability
-Intriguing puzzles

Cons:
-Main story is about twice as long as it should've been .  I had an absolute blast up until about 10 hours in.  Couldn't believe the story kept going. Was just too much of a good thing. 
-At least 1 game breaking bug that forces a checkpoint reload
-It's an indie game so there is no hand-holding. As another reviewer put it: it's easy to spend an hour making no progress without knowing you're making no progress.

39143273.review:
[b]TL:DR[/b]: INFRA is a puzzle game with logical puzzles and a lot of waking around beautiful industrial environments, has a few flaws but is an overall very good game.

If you love urban exploration and urban decay there is a big chance you will love this. Remember those chill sequences in Half-Life 2 where you got to explore desolate places and solve environmental puzzles without enemies bugging you? This is how playing INFRA feels like. INFRA is not without flaws though:
[list]
 [*]Lets start with biggest one in the room - INFRA just LOOOOVES to cut you off from it's optional content - It's not often obvious which way is optional area and which is the main path that will cut you off from any sort of backtracking. Turned right instead of left? Too bad you can't go back now, this will later affect the ending since you didn't take enough pictures.
[*]To add to the above you only have 4 save slots which lead us to the next flaw:
[*]Main menu stylized as protagonist smarphone - very cool looking and original, but comes with a cost of usability - everything is tiny, graphics opitons are limited, you have to scroll the screen instead of seeing everything on one regular window
[*]There are still areas where you can accidentaly trap yourself.
[*]Game has no HUD - good for immersion, but hurts the gameplay a little: most keys that you pick up (but not all) look the same and are not shown anywhere, you have to check all the doors to see which one uses the key you just found. Technically keys have tags on them, but half of the time you can't see what's written on them since tags face away from you. Also 50% of the doors you encounter in game are purely cosmetic and cannot be opened - realistic, but a little frustrating for me as i love to explore and closed doors make me sad.
[*]There is no way to pause the game other than through a console command. It's not a big deal for the gameplay, but there are times where player is required to act fast, and if you get distracted IRL there's no way to pause.
[*]Handwritten in-game texts are sometimes hard to read. Again - realistic, but i would rather have a clean text that's easy to read.
[*]Game uses Half-Life 2: Lost Coast era HDR effect and strong bloom that makes skybox blindingly white at times, the setting is most likely bundled with "effects" parameter in options menu, but i was to lazy to check. I think the game would look beter with it toned down or off.
[*]Not a flaw but rather a nitpick - music only plays during scripted sequences, most of the time you explore with just ambient sounds in background.
[/list]
To adress getting cut from backtracking and trapping yourself you can use noclip cheat (it's not cheating when you fight bugs or poor game design choices)
To end the review on postitive note - the game is really good and i highly recommend it if you like exploration and puzzle solving. One of the areas in the game - Turnip Hill - is one of the best areas in games i've seen in a long time, it's pure genius.

This game really suprised me and surpassed expectations so heres a review.

A wetdream for lovers of industrial atmosphere and detailed gameworlds. If you think you might like this game it might turn into one of the best games you ever played. It all depends on your tastes. If you love the feel of games like Half-Life and STALKER and you also really appreciate exploration, puzzles, and insanely detailed mapping you will love this game. 

You can just tell the developers poured a lot of love and detail into this game. There are tons of little things in the game that most players would probably not even care or notice about, but the sum of the details makes an incredible whole.

The puzzles are not very difficult but they are just hard enough to jog your intuition just a little bit, there are also many optional puzzles and hidden objects you definitely will not find or do the first time around.

My only complaint so far is that the game does not allow you to go back if you accidentally progressed too far in the map before completing the optional puzzles in the game that grant you more insight into the story

Bottom line is this game is not your average indie walking simulator "art" game. This is going to be a cult-classic near masterpiece of a niche genre for a niche group of people who just "get it". 

One of the best and definitely most interesting games of 2016, wish I knew about it sooner.

38915853.review:
INFRA is a story/puzzle game in which you play a structural engineer working for a consulting group that's recently taken over control of a city's infrastructure after its government was sacked for corruption.

The gameplay and premise are both equally engaging.  There's no violence here and the main gameplay involves taking pictures of infrastructure damage (and documents related to that damage) and solving simple mechanical/structural puzzles in order to proceed.  You have a flashlight and camera, both of which you'll have to seek out new batteries to keep powered, but the game never really hides these things in devious places, so you shouldn't have to worry too much about it.

Three things to note:

First, the voice acting is...well, it's not great.  I'll just say that it's probably as good as it can be with the budget the development team were working with and leave it at that.

Secondly, the game does NOT have full controller support as is advertised on the store page.  The controller mapping is not configurable, the game does not ever tell you what the controls for a controller are (all menus and gameplay only show keyboard shortcuts) and the gameplay using a controller is fairly janky.

Thirdly, the game does not have a permanent crosshair option.  By default, the game has no crosshair at all, and the crosshair option that is available only makes it appear when your viewpoint moves close to hotspot.  For a game about finding things in the environment, solving puzzles that sometimes consist of small dials and switches and generally being able to keep your bearings, not having a permanent crosshair as an option is frustrating.

The only bad things I can say about it are:
* The voice acting is actually terrible, specifically the main character.

* Near the end, the game sorta changes from, fun, mostly linear exploration of amazing locations. To, wonder around aimlessly for an hour or two in this boring open location.

38799606.review:
This is definitely one of the best games in my library. The videos in the store page don't show anything spectacular. The premise does not seem attractive enough. Yet I decided to buy because some strange hunch I've had a few times before. The hunch worked flawlessly again.

INFRA looks like an urban exploration simulator. With the difference that you have one reason to be in each location, and not everything is abandoned or wrecked. Moreover, the areas are big, and the attention to detail is impressive. The people who designed this deserves every penny. You can't end with something like this just by guessing how things should look. You need to do your research homework first.

On a side, personal note, though I'm not an urban explorer, when I was a kid, I had the chance of roam several times through a huge industrial complex, with warehouses, factories, machinery, labs, classrooms, offices, gardens, etc. [i]-With my dad's commandment, "OK, BUT DON'T TOUCH ANYTHING", before you ask-[/i]. And the feeling of solitude was something hard to describe, but it remained buried in the past until I played this game. It took me off-guard and it's one of the most astonishing gaming moments of my life.

I'd have to say that as soon as I noticed that sometimes you can reach forbiden areas, I started to invest several hours wandering around, don't caring about the plot. Yes. Exploring the exploration game. Sometimes wondering things like [i]"why is this place so well done? You're not supposed to climb here anyway!"[/i]...I.e., some design holes contributed to add more hours of gameplay, even if the only reward was taking screenshots.

Far from perfection, a bit about the bad:

[list]
[*]Voice acting. At the beginning. I totally disliked the main character voice. Got accustomed with the time, though.
[*]Flashlight battery life. It's excessively short. Like a cheap way of adding some extra difficulty. On a game that tries to depict real scenarios, this is quite an annoyance.
[*]Just a bunch of available save slots, with no way of entering a descriptive title.
[*]Some of the "puzzles" are not exactly puzzles. At least not in an abstract sense. You just need to follow the machinery instructions. Sometimes the instructions are not fully clear so you need to use your logic. [b]I'm FINE with that[/b], but people might feel that they are doing work instead of playing anything.
[*]Too much reading, if you want to keep track of the story. Not required, though.
[*]Deadly waters. Mark Siltanen is officially the cotton-candy man. Water seems to be like sulfuric acid for him.
[*]I'm probably being picky on this one, but sometimes, doors frames, racks or scattered objects block your path more than they should.
[/list]


Finally, I'm very impressed that this game has "Very Positive" reviews considering that a lot of people could criticize its slow pace, sub-par graphics and lack of hints. What an achievement for a game of this kind. Wow, just wow.

38799419.review:
Haastavia pulmia ja ennen kaikkea loistava tutkimusmatka rappeutuneissa suomalaisissa maisemissa. Välillä joutuu selviytymään kelloa vastaan, mutta pohjimmiltaan tämä on rauhallinen peli jossa kävellään ja tutkitaan omaan tahtiin, mikä ei tietenkään kaikille sovi.

Infran 10 varsinaista lukua ilmestyivät kolmessa osassa n. vuoden aikana. Ostohetkellä näistä osista oli tullut vasta ensimmäinen ja koin jo silloin saaneeni rahalle vastinetta. Jokainen (ilmainen!) päivitys sen jälkeen on tullut pelattua läpi lähes yhdeltä istumalta. Voisi jopa sanoa kolmannen osan olleen pelin paras, joten pitkä odotus oli todellakin sen arvoinen. 

Pelin visuaalinen puoli on hoidettu niin hyvin kuin uskon vanhahtavalla Source-moottorilla ja pienellä tiimillä pystyvän. Jotkut kohdat herättivät jopa kunnioitusta kun huomasin miten paljon vaivaa oli nähty luomaan ympäristöistä yksityiskohtaisia ja uskottavia. Äänisuunnittelu on myös huippuluokkaa ja musiikkia käytetään harkitusti luomaan tunnelmaa merkittävissä kohdissa. Tykkään myös viehättävän kömpelöstä ääninäyttelystä, sillä mielestäni se tuo peliin identiteettiä. Hatunnosto tiimille myös siitä, että joskus pelialueen ulkopuolella näkyy muita ihmisiä ja ajoneuvoja. Yleensä tällaiset pelit ovat pelaajaa lukuunottamatta autioita, mikä saa kokemuksen tuntumaan elottomalta.

Suosittelen vahvasti niille jotka pitävät laajojen alueiden tutkimisesta, esineiden etsimisestä sekä tietenkin pulmien ratkomisesta. Onhan siellä myös mielenkiintoinen mysteeri, joka tällaiselle pelille tyypillisesti selvenee erilaisista dokumenteista ja muista lehtisistä. Pelin ratkaisu tuntui erityisen tyydyttävältä, sillä olin ottanut tarpeeksi kuvia saadakseni hyvän päätöksen. Lopuksi täytyy kuitenkin huomauttaa, että minulla on luultavasti Suomen kansalaisena pienoinen ennakkoasenne tähän peliin, sillä erityisesti tutun tuntuisten lähiöiden tutkiminen oli innoittavaa ja jotenkin nostalgista puuhaa.

P.S. ei enää ikinä lauttoja, jooko?

38207062.review:
[b]SCROLL DOWN FOR TL;DR[/b]

INFRA is one of the most interesting Source puzzle games that I've played in ages. Never would have thought that it would be possible to take something as mundane as being a structural analyst, and turn it into a compelling adventure.

The atmosphere and story are great, and Stalburg feels like a fleshed-out city. The sheer amount of environmental storytelling is staggering, and you'll gladly explore to know more. The game is definitely one of the prettier Source engine games... Except when it comes to the humans. Those fall straight into uncanny valley. Luckily, you don't see too many of them during most of the game. The voice acting pretty amateurish, but I don't know how much you can expect from an independent developer with a tight budget.

The puzzle designs are nicely varied and competent, but there are a few segments where you'll get stuck for hours because you failed to notice one teeny tiny detail, because you were so distracted by the bigger picture, or by things literally exploding around you. Some puzzles you can solve in two different ways or even ignore completely, and these affect the routes you can take and the ending that you get.

As a major negative, the game has really infuriating platforming segments over insta-death floors. These wouldn't be a problem, if your character didn't jump like he was wearing concrete shoes. You're gonna need to quicksave and quickload a LOT. There is also one segment with a super fragile pallet raft that will make you rage hard. The major mechanic of pulling yourself up ledges is insanely picky on when it wants to actually work, so you'll be jumping in front of boxes quite a bit before making progress. This can get pretty frustrating during timed puzzles. Finally, sometimes it's very unclear what water is safe and what isn't. Knee-deep water that was safe in one spot, might be an instant death two steps to the right.

INFRA has a lot more replay value than most other games of its type. There are so many things to photograph, fix and collect, not to mention alternate routes, alternate endings and a plethora of hidden content. As for the moment of writing this, I have only one playthrough and already 30 hours in the game, with plenty more content still left to see. If you like puzzle games and exploring, and have plenty of patience, I highly recommend it.

[b]PROS[/b]
+ Great atmosphere
+ Pretty for a Source game
+ Good story
+ Nice puzzles
+ Replay value
+ Lots of hidden content

[b]CONS[/b]
- Bad platforming segments and one bad raft segment
- Picky ledge grabbing
- Inconsistent drowning spots
- Amateurish voice acting

[h1]FINAL SCORE: 8 / 10[/h1]

38099578.review:
TL:DR This game is hands down amazing i would recommend it regardless of the price, its well put together, has a great enviroment, brilliant story, nice mechanics and can keep you busy for hours at a time if you let it. If your into urban exploring this is for you.

My first run was spent mostly looking at the beautiful sceanery, sometimes you can spend a good deal of time just taking in the view and you only need look at the screenshots for that. This turns out to be quite handy because the aim of the game is finding all the cracks and problems with diffrent structures, buildings, etc. As the game progressed i started realising what i should be looking for, the cracks in the walls, steam leaking from pipes, the massive holes everywhere and it got me more and more involved in looking at everything. Basic rule of thumb is if its broken photograph it.

The puzzle mechanics are nice and break up the corridor sections, often you'll find that you hit a big puzzle area, wander around a bit to solve it and then move onto the next corridor leading to a smaller easier challange so that you keep moving. I admit that some areas can be fustrating but if your really stuck theres generally always instructions nearby plus only so many combinations of switches and valves so you'll get there in the end.

The enviroment in this game soon becomes your enemy, not only because of the above mentioned puzzles but also you will spend half the time wondering "does this count", "should i photograph this" and cleverly enough the camera has a nice mechanic to let you know. Also do not be afraid to use your battery's as this is probably the sole reason that you will miss things as you try to conserve them, generally without any need if your observant.

 I fully recommend playing with the headphones on as the sampaling work is pretty amazing and will drag you into the enviroment. The music is great as well and times in at appropriate moments adding to events and milestones.

The story unravels through documents and tapes you find at each site, if you see a piece of paper, book or something written on the wall, read it, so that you understand how everything has come to be the way it is ( then photograph it :P)
Absolutley fascinating way of revealing the story you feel more like a detective rather then a structual engineer. 

Once your done with your first play through, your gonna want to run this again just for the fact that there is so much in it that you'll miss first time round. Keep your eyes open as there are some puzzles that link into later parts of the game. However you have 4 save slots and a quicksave option as well so theres plenty of chances to look back at a puzzle if you think you've missed something.

Big congratulations to the guys that made this game its deffinatly one fo my all time favorites, if you happen to get the chance to adapt this for VR headsets at anytime i think it would really push it to the next level. Just as a nit pick i would have really liked an in game count of the documents and repair sites, maybe as a new game plus bonus or something, but thats just me :P

37999169.review:
Az INFRA fura keveréke egy sétaszimulátornak és egy kalandjátéknak, amiben egy karbantartó mérnök bőrébe bújva kell végigélni egy igencsak érdekes munkanapot. A főnöktől kapott feladat egyszerű rutinnak tűnik, lefényképezni pár aggasztó repedést egy vízerőmű gátján, de aztán a kisebb problémák láncreakciószerűen okoznak egyre többet, szétterjedve a város egészére, teljes káosszal fenyegetve. Így Marknak sokszor a puszta továbbjutásért is ósdi gépeket kell működésbe hoznia, bejárva például egy régi kohót és egy atomerőművet, de bármennyire igyekszik, a vészhelyzet egyre fokozódik. Erre magyarázatul a menet közben összeszedhető dokumentumokból kiderül, az elhanyagoltság nem csak a véletlen műve, a szabotázs mögött pedig egy régi ellentét és a bosszú áll.

Így a játék egyszerűnek tűnik, hiszen csak fényképezgetni kell, meg összegyűjteni pár dokumentumot, de a bejárható terület miatt korántsem lesz könnyű mindent megtalálni. A lineáris történetvezetésért a sok mellékszál, a felfedezhető titkok sokasága (mondjuk hogy a város csatornáiban egy szörny vert tanyát), a bizarr berendezések és helyszínek (például a sajátos szabályok szerint működő, leginkább elmegyógyintézetre hasonlító lakótelep) kárpótolnak, és annak az öröme, amikor sikerül -akár több próbálkozás után- kijavítani valamit, így biztosítva például az ivóvizet a lakosoknak.

Az egyetlen nagyobb hiányosság szerintem egy "inventory", mert amúgy sem könnyű a továbbjutáshoz szükséges aprócska kulcsokat megtalálni, de az még jobban zavart, hogy a legtöbbször ki sem derül, az mit nyit, hogyan segít, hacsak nem az ember akkor megnézi alaposan, mielőtt felvenné. Néha jó, hogy az INFRA nem fogja a játékos kezét, mindenre a feljegyzésekből és a körülményekből kell rájönni, de azért akadnak frusztráló részek is, az ember pedig a fogát szívva fésül át sokadszor négyzetkilométeres területeket, csak hogy mit hagyott ki.

A játék három részben jelent meg, ez már a teljes kiadás.

I've seen this game in early development, and early on I already got excited by seeing teaser screenshots when Part 1 (now known as Act 1) was not even finished yet. Not only does the game look beautiful running on the Source engine (which in my opinion is hard to produce a game on with high quality graphics) but the game mechanics are really unique.

On first sight the game looks nothing more than a puzzle game, but after you do multiple playthroughs you get proven wrong. Depending on how well your eye on details is (capturing everything that's damaged) or how thoroughly you explore your surroundings you can get different endings too. Discovering this later down the line it actually encouraged me to do multiple playthroughs, and after 86 hours of playing I managed to get pretty much all the different endings.

37391373.review:
Plus +:

Graphics: Great environments and, although the character models aren't the best, I feel like it performs well in this feild
Environments: I have always been impressed by industrial environments, and these are no exception. 
Story: Makes sense. Corruption fits nicely together.
Puzzles: Clever, forces you to think but are not unmanageable. I would still say they are quite a bit harder than Portal. 
Realism: All machines, buttons, power plants, are accurate to real life (they aren't replicas, but my father has worked as an electrical operator and comments on the accuracy of the puzzles)
______________________________________________________
Delta Δ:

Lack of people: Some places are just weirdly empty, there are always reasons though, but they are exhausted.
Difficulty: A minority of puzzles are difficult, recuiring you to explore every nook or cranny you might miss. Many people get stuck, but there are tutorials online.
Glitches: There is a glitch at the beginning of chapter 10, where there is an invisible wall in the storage hangar (as of november 2017). Was not there before, noticed it on my second run. There have been other glitches like this throughout the game, especially for achievements, that hopefully will be fixed.
Gross stuff: Some things (aside from dead bodies) look unessesairly gross. Letters smeared in poo and a trash bag full of body parts you need to carry into a food waste bin are a bit too much. 


NOTES:
Length: MUCH LONGER THAN I EXPECTED, about 23 hours to finish without some achievements. The game consists of 10 chapters in 3 parts: 
PART 1: Preparations, Just a regular day at work, Heavy industry of the past, Fresh water
PART 2: Public transport, Working overtime
PART 3: Late for a meeting, To save a city, Redemption
Scariness: You aren't fighting zombies or monsters, but there are some scary horror easter eggs and achievements (???, ERROR: BZZZZZZ, and Underground Justice). Aside from this, there are some dead bodies and bags, adrenalin-high collapsing rooms and gas-fire-hallways. It's a subtle version of scariness.


TL;DR: It's a good game

37092112.review:
INFRA, for the most part, is a first person exploration / hidden object / navigation puzzle game, with a hint of, what should I call it, "environmental suspense", maybe?

Your initial task, as the player character, is to survey a number of neglected installations of various purpose in and around a fictional city called Stalburg, and document any damage you manage to spot by taking photos of them. However, exploring these places often requires you to get through various obstacles ranging from closed doors through malfunctioning equipment blocking your way to flooding, fire, toxic gas and various other environmental hazards. To deal with these, you'll need to find items hidden (sometimes way too well to be considered fun) in the environment, figure out how to fix and/or operate certain machines and other devices, or simply find the right path through a complex environment. As you go from location to location, you'll also come across old documents, which shed light on some dark secrets and conspiracies in the past of the city, and give some insight into why all the places you've visited are in such a poor condition in spite of being critical parts of Stalburg's infrastructure.

The puzzle gameplay of INFRA is a bit all over the place, and it was probably the weakest aspect of the game for me. Some of the puzzles are well communicated and fun to figure out, even many of the more complex mechanical/engineering themed ones have a logical flow which helps you clearly unerstand what needs to be done and giving proper hints as to how to achieve that. And then there are the ones which are completely counter-intuitive, way too drawn out for their own good, or you feel at every step of the way how much effort has been put into obfuscating an otherwise simple task into a jumbled mess of unconnected things to do, or making sure that a key element of the puzzle is hidden in the least likely location in the least visible way. As a whole, it will average out to an ok puzzle experience, but there are qute a few frustrating moments temporarily making the game feel less fun than it actually is.

If some of the puzzles were my personal low, then the architectural design of the various environments you encounter over the course of the game is hands down the best aspect of it. Some unavoidable artistic liberty aside here and there, every single place feels as real as anything you can find in any larger city in the world. The layout of the outdoors areas and the floorplan of the buildings make sense from a practical/engineering point of view, the industrial and other installations are not just a bunch of random machinery thrown together for the looks, but actually follow the technical procedures of whatever was supposed to be taking place at that location, and the detailing of each location helps selling it even more as something "real". Another aspect of the level design, especially in the underground and long abandoned locations is how well it can build and maintain a really tense, even frightening atmosphere without crossing the border into "horror territory" or using cheap tricks like jump scares (although if you are really good at exploring every hidden and remote area, making the connections and thinking a bit outside the box, you may encounter things which will come to you as a shock, quite literally ;). The developers have squeezed every bit of performance out of the Source engine, making the game a sight to behold even compared to some of todays more modern game engines, although at the price of extreme memory requirement. (Don't even think about trying the game at max settings unless you have at least 8 GB system memory. I was like "Oh, Source engine, how demanding can this be? Let's crank it all the way up!" Very bad idea; constant paging, 30 seconds freezes, several minutes loading times level bad.)

And while most games that are built on exploration and puzzles offer little reason to play them again after you've figured things out on your first playthrough, INFRA has a certain level of non-linearity, which makes later maps play slightly differently based on what you did and discovered on previous maps. This means that unless you make the exact same choices and do the exact same things during a subsequent playthrough as in a previous one, the game may play slightly differently this time. And based on your deliberate and accidental actions throughout the game, as well as how attentive you've been in spotting the damage you were sent out to survey and discovering the old documents scattered about, you'll get one of several different endings, which might also be a reason to revisit the game a few more times to try to find what you may have missed in the previous playthroughs.

As a whole, if you don't mind slightly (and at times not even just slightly) annoying puzzles while exploring a real-world looking, beautifully realized and detail rich game world, topped off with a story to piece together about how and why a number of corrupt politicians and businessmen almost brought down an entire city in trying to seize more power and money for themselves, INFRA is an ejnoyable game with a somewhat unique gameplay, nice atmosphere, good music (oh, I didn't specifically mention music, let's just say it's good, I really liked it, and the soundtrack is available if you feel like listening to it again after having heard it in the game) used sparingly,  and enough reason to revisit it a few times if you liked your first run.

INFRA is an exploration and puzzle game, clad in the story of an engineer uncovering the truth about his decaying city. How strongly you are immersed into the story, how much you find out along the way, is entirely up to you. Many core features within the game, including some of the more interesting puzzles, are optional to use and solve.

This game is aimed at the curious natures among the gamers, who do not leave any stone unturned, without being asked to do so. You are no batle hardened soldier, you do not have a backpack full of ingenious tools at your disposal. You are a guy in a hard hat that was tasked to investigate and now has to try hard not to make things worse than they already are. Or maybe he doesn't care? 36573211.review:
Let’s face it, on the surface a game about a ‘structural engineer’ doesn’t sound like the most gripping assignment.

It does sound slightly intriguing in the ‘how can this game be of any interest’ stakes and it certainly could be relaxing, but ultimately it’s a structural engineer for chief’s sake.

The blurb tries to sex it up a bit, highlighting a conspiracy and a fight for survival, and while both are technically applicable, they are both secondary and rudimentary.

This is a walking simulator puzzle game at its core, but to limit it to such a label does it an injustice.

While flawed, and rough, Infra is one of the best indie games you’ll ever play and the depth, quality, length and sheer immersion is as good as any AAA game out there.

Infra sees you play Mark, in the fictional German city of Stahlburg, as said structural engineer who is assigned to inspect the Two Gorges Dam which is said to be in structural peril.

After a very enjoyable little foray around the office it’s time to get to work, and there begins an epic journey through the city of Stahlburg, discovering place after place after secret after secret, all the while ensure you get photos of all the damage and problems you see.

At its core, as said, it is a puzzle game – each place you’ll go to will have something wrong and often you’ll have to fix it  - sometimes these puzzles are so logical, brilliant, and ingenius, and others they’re very poor – it’s a very mixed bag on the quality of the teasers.

The visuals are excellent for a 13 year old engine – it’s on Source, so it has the feel of Half Life 2 very much alive, but it is hugely enhanced in scale, scope and benefits tremendously from 4K – but it’s secondly to the sound, which is just some of the best use of audio you’ll hear in a game.

The voice acting is eccentric but enjoyable, the music pretty immersive but that general ambience is outstanding.

As for the locations – the game is divided into three parts – and the second teaches you a thing or two about claustrophobia. It actually gets frustrating – essentially you’re underground the entire time and you have to earn your route back to the surface, but when you do it is one of the great feelings of gaming. 

I will say this – the game can be uneven. For every two outstanding sections there’s a less inspired or downright poor one. And the amount of underground can be a hindrance more than anything else.

But the thing is meant to be a long hard day at work and it certainly rewards you for the battles you’ll put in to get to the end of it.

Infra is a game which didn’t get much coverage and few people know about it – when it’s bad it’s really insufferable (some bugs as well as some of the design hurt it) but when it’s good it’s absolutely stunning.

It’s a game without enemies, without people to kill, without anyone to shoot. It’s 30+ hours of you with your torch and camera and lots and lots to do and discover.

Highly recommended.

36222469.review:
The game's biggest problem is when its attention to realism butts heads with the limitations of a video game. Some puzzles I got stuck on and had to go look up a walkthrough, and it turned out that either there was a 'that would work in real life' solution that I hadn't thought would be possible in the game, or vice versa. Plus, my sprite got stuck on doorways a _lot_.

THAT SAID, there is something absolutely satisfying about being able to fix things in the world. This game reminds me most of the quiet city exploration levels from Half Life 2. The environments in Infra are big, detailed, and obviously made by people who do understand architecture. These places feel REAL. More than a few times, I had to take a moment to just marvel that someone had designed every little bit of what I was seeing. And you can do more than just gawk, you can make the world better than you left it.  I was smiling every time Mark said, "That should do it!"

There's a lot of other things I could mention, but other reviwers probably also have. The main points are that it's a little unpolished, but also has unique gameplay and is endlessly inventive. It's in my favorites for a lot of reasons.

35994330.review:
Даже не верится, что такую фундаментальную (около 40 часов на обычное прохождение, без нахождения всех секретных мест и достижений) игру сделала небольшая финская студия.

INFRA - это если из Half-Life вырезать стрельбу, скриптовые сценки, диалоги и заменить это логичными инфраструктурными пазлами, исследованием окружения на больших и прилично детализированных локациях (электростанция, лесопилка, дамба, металлургический завод, метро, водоочистные сооружения...) с несколькими путями решения задач, многие из которых опциональны (зато дают ачивки!). 

Играем за инженера-строителя Марка, которому поручено выяснить состояние недавно приобретенных объектов компании. Фонарик и фотоаппарат - наши главные союзники. Несмотря на серьезный бэкграунд, INFRA умело разбавляет атмосферу фирменным финским юмором (мне теперь снятся плюшевые мишки и пиво, о-о-очень много пива) и отсылками к Breaking Bad, Game of Thrones, South Park и пр.

Эксплоринг - самая сильная сторона проекта. Разработчики с выдумкой расположили интересности по местности, всячески поощряя любопытного и внимательного игрока, от действий которого, к тому же, зависит финал игры. В наличии 3 тру концовки и 2 ложные.

Из минусов - бюджетная озвучка и порой низкое графическое качество внутриигровых дневников\записок, приходиться напрягать зрение.

Маленький (на самом деле, большой) инди шедевр. Любителям исследовать окружение - обязателен к ознакомлению.

35957897.review:
The premise of [i]INFRA[/i] contains mystery, intrigue, terror, and numerous conspiracies. Despite the jolly humour and lighthearted beginnings the core atmosphere of [i]INFRA[/i] is filled with dread. Please do not mistake [i]INFRA[/i] as being another typical horror game at first glance, instead think of it as being a first-person "walking sim" on steroids. I highly recommend this to fans of puzzle games in a similar vein to [i]Myst[/i], to those with an appreciation for detail, and to whomever would have the patience to delve into various notes, documentation, and sights in order to slowly extract and piece together this breadcrumb trail of exposition as it balloons into something much larger than anyone could have anticipated.

Based in Finland, [i]INFRA[/i]'s campaign will see the protagonist, Mark, cross an entire city, trying to save himself, whatever, and whomever else he can whilst everything crumbles down around him. My first playthrough of [i]INFRA[/i] offered a playtime of around 30 hours which I can see being doubled in order to discover all the intricacies that this game and its world has to offer.

[i]INFRA[/i] is an absolutely stellar game where developer, Loiste Interactive, displays an insane attentiveness in regards to the detail and quality of the game and its world: from incredibly complex story lines where each branching narrative and its characters are subtly interwoven and eventually come together in the end; having each chapter's set pieces tastefully hide tonnes of pop-culture references and further important revelations to the story that can easily be overlooked as just another in-game texture; containing puzzles that may require the player to accomplish something seemingly insignificant in the first few hours of gameplay that won't prove its usefulness until the final act; and a masterful handle of the Source Engine with massive, sprawling levels and visual tricks that keeps the adventure interesting and occasionally provoking a sense of true horror.

For fans of point and clicks from the '90s to the present day, for anyone who enjoys puzzles with a logical and methodical solution, and for those who want to experience something completely different and who have an appreciation for detail, [i]INFRA[/i] provides all of that and more. There is no doubt in my mind that [i]INFRA[/i] is my game of the year for 2017 and one of the best adventure/puzzle games I have ever had the pleasure of playing.

View my [url=https://www.twitch.tv/collections/2uqZjG3C6xRldA]playthrough of INFRA[/url] on Twitch.

35944857.review:
This game made me want to be a structural analyst.

While not traditionally "graphically impressive" (which may be from the choice of engine), INFRA still manages to stun with its environments. The massive open vistas of dilapidated industrial facilities and the winding service tunnels beneath both play in the Source engine's favour. That the game's main focus is on observing the environment says something about how good it looks; it comes under scrutiny far more often here than in other games, and I can't say I saw more odd seams and glitches than in any AAA title.

The puzzles vary in difficulty, and they don't really follow a clear difficulty curve (except for some of the later puzzles having a time limit), which is not really a problem as the focus of the puzzles is more about fitting into the world. They do that amiably.

The humour of the story is typically Finnish, something I really love, and the "ambient narrative" about corruption is told in a really cool way. Any questions about why certain parts of the environment is the way it is can be answered by the scattered notes. They way sidequests have consequences further down the line is also very neat.

 I worry that some people may miss important parts if they don't read everything they photograph. I started out thinking that the documents weren't supposed to be read because of the almost-transparent ink colour and the low resolution, but after a while I realized that wasn't the case. That's definitely a point of future improvement, overall texture quality is on the low end, and for the documents it's on the verge of being unacceptable. It is still readable with some effort.

The absolutely worst part of the game is unfortunately the voice acting. I can see that this really was a labour of love and I hate to be negative about such a thing as someone's voice, but the quality overall is low and the main character is just awful. He gets the enunciation wrong in just about every line of the game. I get that he's supposed to be a Finn, but Finns usually speak English a lot better than this. He also doesn't "sound like a surveyor". It's really a nitpick, but it goes a long way to help immersion. Someone like Grady from the Practical Engineering YouTube Channel is more of what I'd select as a voice actor, with proper enunciation and an air of professionalism.

All in all, a top-notch experience with some minor hiccups, which shouldn't be missed by anyone who has even a minor interest in infrastructure. If you can't stand the main character, that's understandable. Fortunately, he speaks relatively little.

35874688.review:
Unsung excellence.  Why isn’t this game much better known? 

It’s hard to summarise Infra but that’s because it doesn’t fit any obvious genre. It has Myst-like puzzles but it’s not just a puzzle game. Then there are bleak underground areas with a heavy sense of dread in the air but without horror monsters to face. And it's all joined up with huge detailed explorable areas which would grace a AAA blockbuster. It combines these beautifully to give you (in my case) 50 hours’ worth of unhurried playability in the first run through without a single enemy to fight or weapon to fire. And the perfect pacing maintained my enthusiasm to keep going every step of the way.

The jewels in the crown for me though are the fabulously detailed industrial environments. I’ve worked in places which have plant, switch panels, pipelines, ladders, cable trays etc. [i]exactly[/i] like this. The dev team and artists have got this absolutely spot-on; the immersion here is total, right down to the tatty control rooms and abandoned workshops with tools, coffee cups and notes left by long-gone workers. Each one had its own challenge and “Aha!” moment of satisfaction to slowly tease out before you could move on.

Criticism? Well, the logic of some of the switch & valve puzzles can be a little off-piste. There was one in particular which required [spoiler] a stuck valve to be freed by throwing three bricks into the mechanism [/spoiler]. I’d still be there now if it wasn’t for the walk-through. And there are a few timed puzzles which I for one dislike. I’m an older gamer and don’t have a young person’s quick reactions, so I just die dozens of times over before getting through. No fun there, just stress and broken immersion. So that would be my one change request: an “easy mode” option to globally increase the timeout on all timed puzzles to make them more easily achievable for players like me.

But in the end, they all added to the quirkiness of this unique world.  So it’s 10 out of 10 for me, I loved it.

35808621.review:
I really enjoyed this game. A big fan of non-violent exploration games, this hit my sweet spot. You explore huge areas – each with their own atmosphere and secrets to explore. I enjoyed the solitude, but you don't feel completely alone, you get phone calls from your office, and you talk to yourself occasionally. It has its own unique feel and logic to it. I give it a big thumbs up. I did find several of the puzzles, especially the ones in the last third of the game, to be too difficult to understand without looking up online, mostly because it takes place at night, and that really amped up the difficulty of being able to find clues and doors.  I wish we got the super long-lasting battery flashlight sooner ;-(

The whole experience of exploring abandoned buildings, sewers, caves, towns, water treatment plants, and other urban jungle remains, made you feel like you were really there. I just completed the game, and I'm looking forward to replaying the whole things from the beginning again and taking in the sights once again.

Voiceover is plain and pure fail. I have never heard voice actors, even amateur ones, fail som miserably to deliver their lines. I literally had LARPs with more character and emotions than this ramrod stiff delivery.

Fun fact: you can have a tablet for logging down important details, having a GPS map of the facilities, etc... except you CANNOT! The company you're playing the role of the employee of bought them for everyone, but you cannot even pick one up.

It's a game about dipalidated stuff. A very dilapidated game in and of itself.

AVOID!

Oyunun başında verilen bazı yapıları denetleme görevi aslında oyunun bir yürüme simülasyonu olduğunu düşündürmüştü. Ancak oyun bundan çok daha fazlasıymış.

35488715.review:
This is a serious little jewel of a game. If you like exploration, and long rewarding gameplay I very seriously urge you to check this one out. Despite how there are some dark, even mild tension inducing parts in the game it's overall a very relaxing, chill experience. This isn't one to be rushed! The game is very long - and even so it manages to keep the player interested and immersed. I found no part boring myself. There are some minor, vexing inconveniences; such as the terribly energy hungry camera and flashlight. But to be fair there are plenty of batteries really, and managing them isn't terribly challenging. Some bugs here and there; that is an unfortunate little downside to this game. Nothing that can't be managed though. 

There is a very well spun, even a somewhat complex story and plot in the game; but there are also plenty of hidden easter eggs and strategically sprinkled bits of humour to keep it from becoming too serious. I'm a bit conflicted on weather one can call it a walking simulator. On some ways I suppose the term can be partially accurate here - but keep in mind there are plenty of puzzles and exploration to keep you more active than your usual "walking simulator" would. At least in my humble opinion. 

If one is a fan of a chill, exploration experience, I seriously urge you to check this little gem out. Even more so if you happen to Finnish like myself; there are plenty of little jokes us Finns will definitely notice and apperciate. (there are even a couple of references to Kummeli; I won't spoil and say what and where they are but they made me laugh when I found them!) 

Finally I'd like to just praise the environments. They are absolutely beautiful, even if you find yourself inside a crumbling, rusty decrepit damn or outside in the more foresty, shiny areas. Rust or lush greenery, it's all wonderfully created. I have nothing but respect and love for the devs here! 

I DEMAND MOAR. 

All in all: Great, fun, long rewarding gameplay, wonderful silly little easter eggs (especially if you're a Finn), enjoyable puzzles and hell, it's just great fun. You also feel sympathy for the poor player character. Really isn't having a very good day :P 

Please consider buying this if you like long, rewarding exploration games.

35474549.review: INFRA is easily one of my favourite games of all time, it's got tricky puzzle elements, large and expansive environments, and an interesting and compelling story. 背景是現代城市，故事不是恐怖主題的步行模擬游戲幾乎是不存在。。。這游戲滿足了！第一關就是一個精心製作的辦公大樓，而且整個游戲下來地圖的設計真是精心得令人髮指，怪不得整個游戲體積如此大。

可惜的是故事的敘事做得不夠好，比較平淡羞澀，也沒有大風大浪，雖然主角（或者説我）還死了很多遍。我要是一天的工作要這麽長而且走這麽多路還這麽危險，絕對辭職。。。

J'ai vécu une superbe aventure, même si j'ai eu du mal à saisir l'entiereté du scénario, en raison d'un jeu complètement en anglais (pas de sous-titres pour les dialogues, et beaucoup de documents à lire).
Aussi, en cas de difficulté, il faut savoir que beaucoup de puzzle sont optionnels (mais les résoudre permet d'ouvrir une porte à la fin je crois - impossible d'en être sûr n'ayant pas tout résolu justement).

Enfin bref, un jeu que je referai sans aucun doute, et que je recommande à tous les fans de jeu de puzzle logique.

35315593.review: Crumbling monoliths of concrete and steel. Valves to turn, buttons to push, levers to pull, a city to save. Government negligence and a corporate conspiracy.  A game with a message? Definitely! More importantly, an epic 25-plus hours ode to the Source engine, virtual urban decay, machine puzzles, and having the final word in all of them. No zombies to kill or simulators to walk here—just puzzle after puzzle after puzzle, elevated to new heights by a mind for what matters, a darkly eccentric comic instinct, and the greatest level design to ever grace the [gracefully-ageing] Source engine. Is it without flaws? Of course not! Prerequisite vehicle sequence #1-too-many, a power-hungry portable image-taking gizmo in constant need of fresh batteries, and a listless middle act will have you itching for less, but the pitch-perfect Part 3 of the whole $25 shebang will drag you back in with a vengeance. The perfect companion to the existential dread of urban collapse hitherto conquered by Condemned: Criminal Origins (minus the bloodthirsty hobos), the precarious navigation of hazardous environments of the Half-Lifeian kind (minus the iffy first-person platforming), and the anxiety-inducing quiet and poke-and-prod puzzling of Myst (minus the impossibly oblique leaps of logic), all brought down to surreal earth. Buy it!

35287902.review:
Bought this last year, now the full edition is out thought I would give it a go. Genuinely one of the [i]best[/i] mix of exploration, puzzle, and mystery game I have played (or seen). Believable and down-to-earth story gets you hooked and engaging gameplay wandering through the derelict brownland, taking in the sights of the beautifully crafted world that portrays the idea that these buildings have been long abandon and nature has taken hold. Puzzles themselves are quite fun to work out, and an internal feeling of doing soemthing good rushes through you everytime you solve one. I found the puzzles less frustrating than when I played the likes of Portal, but they are by no means simplier, harder if anything. 
I was very surprised that the first chapter took me around 2.5 hours, as was expecting a small indie game, if price to game time ratio is what you base your purchases on then gamelength seems great for that.
Looking forward to many more hours with INFRA.

- [i]modern day realism.[/i] no horror or fantasy element at all, everything is based on modern this day stuff. (there is 1 horror/spooky aspect in the game but it's just an easter egg from the dev so you can completely skip it)

- [i]setting and atmosphere is great.[/i] the graphic is not nextgen quality, but still more than enough to make you enjoy the  surrounding scenery

- puzzle difficulty is manageable. it start easy and gradually increase it's difficulty and complexity but still enjoyable throughout the game, i played until part 2 and only need guide in 4 specific puzzle

- [i]semi open.[/i] one great thing about this game is that the game will often put you on the spot with a lot of pathway which you can  explore at your own leisure. its not open world but its not "corridor" exploring either, the game somehow give you a "false feeling" of freedom to explore, but at the same time still manage to "guide" you as to where to go next.

- [i]sense of exploring.[/i] another thing that i like from this game is that you actually explore the building and the surounding area, there is no 'stage clear" or you end up to totally different area in abrupt way. you start from A and slowly progressing to B and C and so forth, it feel serene and very zen like sometimes.


[b]things that people might hate:[/b]
- [i]music.[/i] there is almost no music in this game, even if it's there it's mostly ambient sound.

- [i]missable stuff.[/i] because the amount of path you can explore, you will miss a lot of thing  like document, letter, object to photo, etc, some of this stuff is lock behind puzzle and well hidden, the game really demand you to explore every nook and cranny if you want to get everything.

- [i]no indicator.[/i] aside from highlighting stuff you can pick up or interact, there is nothing else. the game give you no waypoint, no objective marker, no inventory, not even a hud, what you see is what you get.

- [i]clunky movement.[/i] you move slow even when you run, also jumping and climbing is very stiff which is bad considering this game is all about exploring.

- [i]cheap death.[/i] you will die quite a lot in this game, and half of it usually from your own stupidity (the rest is because you are not sure of what to do and out of time), thankfully the game give you save/load anywhere and everywhere. 


[b]one small nitpick:[/b]
[i]emptiness.[/i] aside from very early in the game, you will meet no one else, you will occasionally speak on your phone but thats about it. in a fantasy or horror game this is natural, but in this game it feels weird.

some of the place you go has obvious sign of someone living there but you always encounter no one, its understandable if you are in uncommon place like abandon building, sewer, underground tunnel and such. but even when you are in the middle of city, there is no living on sight not even a cat or dog despite i'am at the part of city surrounded by homes and apartments but, nope not even a soul.

aside from that, the game is great and i hope the dev can make more quality games in the future =)
