24366046.review:
INFRA Is a game with a lot of good concepts and a style that looks somewhat similar to the Stanley Parable and Half Life 2, with a lot of simplified almost to clean models and well as a reasonable amount of appropriate clutter items to flesh out a scene.  The central story encourages exploring never nook and the game does not disappoint, at least at first.  If you go into the game assuming a certain level of exploration with fix it logic then you will enjoy much of this game, but will likely find your enjoyment level to drop significantly around the end of chapter 3/beginning of chapter 4 and I'll explain why.  There are two primary problems with the game's current set up.  The first is the scope of what is going on, which balloons in a hurry and in a way that loses credibility due to where its happening, which is a shame.  If handled on a much slower build and if the game had kept its locations remote it would have worked brilliantly.  I will avoid any spoilers in this this explanation but just know that the locations in this game start off remote, possibility believable that they have been abandoned for decades, and then moves on to locations that smack in the middle of cities in a way that they can't have been ignored that long.  The size of the levels also grows significantly, which makes there placement less credible.  If they had remained remote it would have worked much better.  
The second and id would argue bigger problem is that the physics engine, or physics interactions suck.  This will not be a problem until the point I mentioned above, where you will start to encounter area after area of instant death traps which require precise object placement.  There is no rotate option, the items bounce around and one mistake and your back to your last save.  These sections, unlike the exploration and fixit puzzles that i enjoyed so much, rapidly drained my enjoyment of the game, as they involved huge set pieces of "how do i get out of here".  The lack of inventory interface is irksome, but i can understand the thematic reason for it.  As the character mentioned how many packs of batteries he has one picking a new set up.  A command to have character due a verbal check would have been useful.
To the developer, I see a lot of good things in this game and I hope the second part is ever better.  If you don’t; want to add in human models keep the locations remote.  But please rework the controls and get rid of the water hazards.  Your strength is in useful interactive exploration, not physics obstacles.
To the rest of you, despite its flaws, I would give it try, just be aware the flaws are there

24359758.review:
This is a hard game to recommend, even though there were a LOT of good things about it.  I think this is a unique setting for a game and everything in the game looks great.  I loved poking around in these old crumbling and rusting contrete buildings/structures.  There is a compelling framework for a great game...  I just think they fell a little short.

For example, the puzzles aren't particularly challenging.  The mechanics are good and it could be fun if they were a bit more difficult and even rewarding.  I found myself wanting to get the equipment working again (which would've been rewarding), but really you had to get it working enough to get through the level, and then everything crubles behind you most of the time.  You actually do a lot of damage for someone who's supposed to be inspecting things.

There are also some inconsistencies to the world.  Slight spoiler/valuble tip:  [spoiler]Early in the game, touching most water is an insta-kill (GTA3 like, even).  But then later in the game, you have to jump off a ledge into murky water and, suprise, you can walk around no problem.  I had to watch a youtube video for that.[/spoiler]

That could be better, or there could be a compelling story that keeps you moving forward.  There's a attempt at a plot, but the scraps are so far and few between that you don't remember any the names or what's going on.  There are newspaper articles that have a lot of background info, and they have general world building, but I couldn't put the pieces together.  Maybe the designer looked at this stuff as a whole, but when it was spread over 10ish hours of gameplay all the intricacies and the interconnected bits were lost.

So again, this is sort of a regrettable not recommended.  I wanted to like it, but in the end I was just watching youtube videos almost right away because I wanted to finish it.  I think the designers (or you) should take a look at SOMA.  I wasn't a fan of the horror element, but it also had a beautiful world, lots of walking, and similar mechanics.  But there was a compelling story, the puzzles you solved accomplished something, and there was a lot less backtracking.

24317922.review:
I also covered this game on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jzf1IveLS-s

INFRA's a fascinating title. It's most definitely a narrative exploration game, often known by the semi-derogatory term "walking simulator." I'm not a fan of this genre. I thought Dear Esther and Gone Home were pretentious, overpriced dreck. Yet, there's something compelling and fascinating about this game because it deals with what seems like an utterly boring and bland subject in a fascinating way.

INFRA tells the story about an engineer who is sent to a dilapidated, rural power generation site to assess and document the damage. This place is not only a wreck but along the way, you'll discover a twisted story happening behind the scenes. There's no combat and so overt scares, though you may get started a couple of times. The core of the game involves exploring the surprisingly large environment, solving clever but often infuriating environmental puzzles to progress and taking pictures along the way. The pictures are optional but help flesh out the story more and are also tied to achievements.

There's a minimal amount of voice acting, though what you do hear is pretty cringey. It's a minor part of the experience though and doesn't detract much. What surprised me is the amount of content here for the money. INFRA's environment is massive and even though it runs on the Source Engine (it was originally a mod), it looks absolutely gorgeous and provides a really immersive environment. While researching my video, I regularly just stopped and took in the environment, something I rarely do in any game. Though you're in a wrecked environment and it is stressful, it's also frequently relaxing and zen. Most people are taking between 16 and 18 hours to finish INFRA and this is just the first half of the game. It was split up into two parts but the second part will be free and the developers are saying it'll be a similar length. Given that Gone Home was 90 minutes for $20, $15 for what could be over 30 hours is a frankly staggering value proposition.

If you're really opposed to any game in this genre, INFRA won't change your mind. However, this team took something as seemingly boring and uninteresting as photographing a run down power dam and made it a compelling, beautiful experience with a great mystery behind it. If you're unsure if INFRA is for you and my video doesn't help sway you, give it a try. It may surprise you. It certainly did me.

24307790.review:
This, to me, is exactly what Greenlight is for. This is probably one of the strangest, most unlikely ideas for a game I have ever seen actually work. If you're a fan of anything remotely like Gone Home, Firewatch, Dear Esther, Everybody's Gone to the Rapture, etc, etc you'll love this. I think it's a good deal better than all of those, except for Firewatch, which I think is the high-water mark for 'walking sims'.

[b] Pros [/b]

- The world is beautiful. I absolutely love the way everything looks in this game. And the detail is great. It really looks like every, single thing was paid attention to in making this game. Old, neglected rooms feel grimy and worn. Everything is dusty looking and gritty. They actually look like real rooms that haven't been touched in years. And then the newer buildings are bright and clean. Everything shiny. You don't just walk through a world where you feel like the developer just recycled the same things over and over, even when you are in a place where it's essentially the same things over and over; it doesn't feel that way.
- The developer's seeming knowledge is impressive. It doesn't feel like a subject he just guessed at. It feels very convincing.
- For the most part the puzzles feel logical and real. They're not 'video game puzzles'. A lot of puzzle games, particularly older point-and-click type games suffered from puzzles where you were just trying through trial and error to figure out what the developer wanted you to do and not really applying real-life thought to anything. I haven't had to check a walkthrough yet, even though some of the puzzles can get a little confusing, but I always felt like I could figure them out using the same thought processes I would use in real life.
- The sound is amazing in the game. Very immersive.
- The game runs fantastically. I haven't had any crashes or glitches or framerate issues or anything. It runs better than a lot of AAA titles while looking just as good as many of them.
- The story sounds completely bonkers, but it unfurls in a way that hooks you. I read the description for this and I thought, 'This is not a game. This is walking sims and novelty job sims gone mad,' but decided to chance it based on the other reviews. I'm amazed at how addictive and compelling it is. I would urge anyone who hears, 'You play as a safety inspector,' and thinks that it sounds horrible to give it a shot. You'll be pleasantly surprised, I think.
- I LOVE the camera. The fact that it's a real camera that you bring out and use the way you would an actual camera is brilliant. I wanted to snap photos of everything.

[b] Cons [/b]

- The voice acting is a bit of a mixed bag. When there are two or more people talking to each other it comes across as robots talking. Dialogue is stilted and awkward, they're speaking over one another, the repsonses seem out-of-place and devoid of any emotion. Even when people are hearing shocking news they'll say something in a totally flat, bored voice, 'Oh, really? Ok. See you later.'
The game actually opens with someone saying, 'Oh hi, Mark,' and I'm legitimately unsure if this is a purposely nod to the horrible acting in the film, The Room, or not.
- The only way to access the options menu is from the opening menu before you enter the game. It caused a little minor irritation when I was trying to find how I wanted to play the game early on (hints on or off, subtitles on or off, crosshairs, etc) and I had to save and exit the game anytime I wanted to experiment with any of these.
- Actually moving through the world can be a little tedious at times. Your character, Mark, is almost the exact same width as every door, so it's very easy to get stuck just trying to walk around and then you have to jig left and right to get through.
- There's no inventory. You can pick up an assortment of labeled keys in the game and there were a few times I picked up some keys and then found a sign that would explain where keys could be found and I would wonder if they were the keys I'd already picked up, but there was no way to check their tags again. Same with batteries. Mark tells you how many packs he has when you pick up more, but if you forget there's no way to check.
- I wish that when you picked up some items like wheels and spare parts that they went into your unseen inventory like keys and batteries do so that you wouldn't have to walk around with a giant object floating directly before your eyes.
- No map. This just doesn't make real-world sense to me. You find maps scattered everywhere. Why does Mark not collect them to consult later? Or let us check photos that we've taken of these maps. It just doesn't make a lot of sense to me that he would go into these massive labyrinthine places with no guidance at all of where he is or where he's going.

I had to ask myself what the hell had I just bought, I began looking for the refund button. The first 5-10 minutes are spent wondering around said office block collecting your equipment before setting off to the job.
It's when you arrive at the Hydro Dam that the game really begins and a wonderfully crafted setting can be enjoyed to the full. It took me 11 hours to complete but then I do love wondering around these realistic worlds and taking in the views, so it can be done much more quickly if thats what you prefer. 
As you can probably tell I love good graphics in my games and this one is up there with the best. In places it reminds me of another beautiful looking game,The Vanishing Of Ethan Carter, although this game takes place underground a lot. I hope part two is as good as part one. I can't wait.

23966061.review:
INFRA - неоднозначная, но крайне качественная в визуальном плане игра, которая может затянуть игрока в свой мир на несколько часов. В игре присутствует большое количество механических и электрических пазлов, которые вам придётся решать для того, чтобы продвигаться по уровню. Особое внимание стоит отвести звуковому сопровождению и вниманию к реалистичным деталям, которые во многих играх любят упускать.

[h1]Основные плюсы:[/h1]
* Выскококачественная детализация окружения
* Отличное звуковое и музыкальное сопровождение
* Атмосферные мини-события
* Интересные пазлы, которые имеют место в реальной жизни
* Огромные уровни, реализованные на движке-старичке Source Engine
* Несколько часов увлекательного игрового процесса

[h1]Основные минусы:[/h1]
* На первом уровне многие персонажи сделаны посредственно и низкокачесвенно (вырываются из стилистики игры)
* В некоторых моментах становится крайне непонятно, куда следует идти дальше и что требуется от игрока

[i]В целом, игра заслуживает высокой оценки и крайне рекомендую любителям атмосферных пазлов от первого лица.[/i]

23936912.review: Enjoyed the game, very cool places to venture into. Please make a part 2 somehow.

23901883.review:
If you've ever wandered through the levels in Half-life 2 and thought to yourself "Why is no one taking care of this place?"
Then INFRA is for you!

At it's core, INFRA is really just a game about walking(or sprinting!!!) around and taking pictures of things that are broken, or damaged.
However, the core gameplay is spiced up with tense creepy atmosphere, big levels, interesting puzzles and hidden story bits and mysteries. All of this combined kept me hooked for 12 hours, enjoying every second.

There are many things to be fixed, atmosphere to experience, and ways to get yourself killed! Thorough exploration will reward the player with additional backstory, and help them uncover bigger mysteries. 

My biggest criticism of the game, is the lack of 'reward'. You get a camera in your hands, and is told to take pictures of damages and broken things. It honestly seems like there is no point to this, the achievements to be aquired for this are very very long term progresses. 
I wish there had been, even the tiniest of rewards for finding and photographing the most awkward of things. Perhaps have the protagonist drop a few comments? 
I can see that something like that would be very time consuming to implement, but would give the player more reason to search for every lose pipe screw. (I did so anyways)

I will close out by saying that while i personally recommend the game, i would be careful with whom i recommend it to. If you are NOT into explorative, non-combat puzzle games, this is not for you.

On the other hand, i enjoyed every second of this game, and I am great anticipating Part II !

23888665.review:
The game starts off promising with interesting environmental puzzles and world-building, but gradually replaces its claustrophobic loneliness and reflections on the banality of corruption and decay with over-the-top action set pieces and overwrought conspiracies that ultimately detract from some of its best charms.

To be honest, the game is downright schizophrenic with its tone and focus. On the one hand, you'll find yourself faced with some intriguing problems, and if you take the time to walk through them you'll find yourself gradually pushing back the inevitable collapse of the city's forgotten infrastructure. But you don't have to. You could just progress onward, building bridges over the rubble of the past never once looking back.

This is a pretty great choice for this game, but it's implemented so poorly you wonder why it was an option at all. As mentioned before, the game loves throwing you into skin-of-your-teeth breakneck action sequences, which would be fine every once in a while but becomes the bread and butter of the last half of the game. As a result, puzzles you were in the middle of solving get swept away in a flood or a pile of rubble and you're simply pushed onward into the next segment leaving your latest project frustratingly half-finished. What's worse, there's never any subtle clue that what you're doing is about to gate you off from any previous content -- you simply walk into a room and suddenly everything hits the fan.

One could almost forgive it if the game was instanced or modular in such a way that you simply can't retrace your steps due to the code. But several times you have complete and unfettered access to massive stretches of territory you casually walked out of, including an entire chapter. Speaking of which, the last half of this game abandons its close-knit and focused puzzle environments for a sprawling, endless city barred off increasingly by artificial gates and doors that you will never be able to open, giving it an awkward sense of padded uselessness.

It's a pretty good game but abandons its own promise to stretch out its length at the end.

23846312.review:
I wish INFRA stayed closer to the "First Person Inspector" game it looked like it was going to be (and started off as). In the end, it was like they were trying to make a game like Half Life 2 without guns and did a really poor job of it. Unfortunately, many of the puzzles were not well designed. There was a lot of backtracking and items hidden in unknowable places.

I'll keep my eyes open for INFRA 2, but hopefully the developer takes the opportunity to improve on the gameplay. Please also get some voice actors who can have a conversation that sounds natural.

インフラに関わる様々な風景を楽しむ　という目的が達成されたのでとりあえず満足

[h1]良かった点[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]風景が綺麗[/b]
メインの目的だけあって、荒廃した感じも綺麗な感じも両方よく出来てます。
ネタバレなのでいえませんが、道中で2箇所綺麗だなーと思う場所がありました

[*][b]人の痕跡を見るのが楽しい[/b]
portalの裏部屋のような人の痕跡がしょっちゅう出てきます。

ただし、他のレビューに日本語化されている方がいらっしゃる様子なので調べてみてください。
あと標準だと字幕がついていないので、ヒアリングを頑張りたい人以外は字幕を設定した方がいいでしょう。

インフラを眺めるのが目的ですし、アクション性が変わることを期待しているわけでもなく、インフラのジャンルもいろいろと変えてくれてるので問題ない。
はずなんですが、退屈に思う瞬間が有りました。謎解きが似てるからでしょうか。

Part2が来たのでやりましたが、ちょこちょこ山場はあるものの全体的に似た流れでした。Part1から続けてやるとちょっと退屈かもしれません。(17/2/12)


 [*][strike]実は完結しない

Part3が出て完結してました。なかなかのボリュームだったのですぐに色々回収しようという気にはなりませんね。日本語MOD完結したら最初からやろうかなあ。結構文量ありそうだから大変そうです。(18/2/21)

23798422.review:
This game had the chance to be good in my book.  Unfortunately my time was spent looking through a guide with vague directions when the game was even more so with what I was supposed to do.  I'll give you a scenario right now:

I after going through a frustrating 'puzzle' of moving boxes to jump across shallow electified water (That may I add any inspector with properly equiped rubber boots would be able to walk through easily) where sometimes I'd fall in a crack between the boxes that is close to impossible to be the size of the actual character, was lead into a control room with many interactble buttons that I messed with, to later find out where there FOR NO REASON BUT TO CAUSE CONFUSION, and after passing by all of those I go into a saw mill with in the darkness some sort of pulley system, I let it loose and make a hole in the floor to go down it look around and find that oddly in the basement are MORE POWER GENERATORS that I have to turn on but when I do it takes a few seconds then kills me in what looks like ankle deep water.  Again, the rubber boots thing saves lives.  Anyways I go back down there flip the lever run up hop over a wall instead of just have it locked like another door I had to get the keys for earlier, go into some cabin that's been abandoned for years in the most unlikely way possible (climb a ladder up the roof and fall down on some sort of wood shutter that's held by some string strong enough to hold our weight to climb into the attic) get some guys keys into a mineshaft that for some reason is related to the power system we're inspecting.

That was only a PART of my time with Chapter 2.  3 from what I played involved a switch puzzle that only existed because the lines weren't managed professionally, and something that was literally filp all the switches on, turn it on, then hit reset and you know all this by reading a note placed right next to it all.  It was then I realised that this game is a puzzle game based on cheap tricks that are 'puzzles' only because it takes a minute at most for you to turn something on and it was also based on hiding what you're actually supposed to do, I thought I was only investigating the actual power plant, why am I in a cave now.  I only got more confused by this game as it went on.

Alright now time for the graphics, while they're actually good for an indie game and the price I cant say I enjoyed a lot of the enviorment design, in chapter one the graphics were the poorest some models looked phoned in and textures were sometimes large part solid color, that was the worse of it, chapter 2 the starting area sums it up pretty well.  A lot of green outside, green, green, green making it harder to believe.  And the interior is grey dirty and overall just ugly.  I'm just going to say this ugly is ugly even when intentionally made ugly.  From what I saw of chapter 3 the game was only moving more toward that.

The soundtrack was never played, its odd I remember it badly but going back and listening to it it sounds fine, maybe even good.  I hope for their "Episode 2" they utilize it more because while the tracks are short they're enjoyable and might be good for ambience.

I am actually sad I couldn't enjoy the story it seemed like it had something written but we already know what's going to happen from our surroundings in the very start of the game we're told we were handed this place off FOR A CORRUPTION SCANDAL.  I don't know about you but when I already know essentially the end from the start the stories lose something to me, it's the same with movies recently, with their trailers showing the ending bits since those are the best.  I was hoping to hear more of the characters dialog from when the company went bankrupt, but unfortunatly I stopped myself over gameplay not story.  Also on that front voice acting is horrible not for the recording enviorments changing or anything like that but the direction, at some times the voice sounds like a COMPLETELY OTHER PERSON, some lines change from one to the next with voice and THATS why I think it's bad.

Since part two is coming out I hope that these complaints are fixed by then, maybe with a update to the previous maps/levels to clarify things like objective, maybe a in game hint system, or maybe just a log/diary of some sort that records more precise thoughts of the protaganist that will give you a strong idea of where to go / what to do, maybe with a pre done or a hand drawn map to give a sense of where you've been / where to go, as that's the main thing that made my time with this game poor.  Also lower gravity or raise jump power a bit and enable always run or something to make our movement go faster as the walking simulator complaints are something I felt while playing.

23519940.review: Truthfully I'm hooked on this game.  You get to explore in some beautiful surroundings unraveling a very fascinating story.  For me it was like the exploration you got to do in Half-life with some of the creepiness of Penumbra but more exploring and  less creepiness.

23439911.review:
I was very pleasantly surprised with the game. It looks great considering the aging engine. (It would be amazing on modern engines) It's very atmospheric and I just love crawling in every place looking for easter eggs and more things to photograph. (and if you're careful you can find plenty of batteries. I had 10/10 for both almost all the time in last episodes) 

Some people complaing about the protagonist's voice acting but I find it very fitting for what I imagine the guy is like :) The game has a lot of easter eggs, hidden things, things that only Finnish people understand (+/-) and on top of that extreme attention to small details. I found a phone number in random poster after the cave early in the game and much later I could call the number for some additional fun. Plenty of things like that. 

The basic gameplay consists of walking around looking for structural damage / other things that need maintenance or documents exposing corruption and then snapping a photo of them. May not sound very exciting but the beautifully aged environments make if very enjoyable. For me at least. The game really rewards exploration. 

There are also a number of puzzles which vary from simple to slightly more complex ones but  you don't have to solve them all (Unless you're looking for 100% completion) Good thing about the puzzles is that usually they are rather logical. There are few places where you have to do some precision jumping but if you've played any fps games it's nothing too difficult. 

There is also bigger plot behind the whole thing which slowly unravels as you find new clues and stuff. I have to pay more attention to it on the next playthrough but it seemed interesting enough. Anyway I'm really looking forward to part 2 and want to congratulate the devs for great work so far. 

As a sidenote I bought the game for my 70 year old father who enjoys playing Myst type games and he at least seems to have enjoyed the experience even if some areas that require nimble fingers were causing additional grey hairs for him :) 

As a final warning I'd like to point out that if you're looking for continuous action and get bored of exploring places just for the sake of exploring you may not enjoy the game as much as I did.

23392353.review:
《INFRA》故事背景设定在一个名叫“Stalburg”的腐败城市，游戏中将化身为工程师，每天都在工厂检查设备，玩家必须运用智慧和经验在生存和真理之间找到平衡。玩家将身在一个地下铁路，游戏中可以使用手机拍照找寻线索、收集可用的物品。场景中设计了各种机关，玩家需要思考、解谜，才可以不断地前进。
  这是一款没有枪战的生存探索游戏，换而言之就是木有大爆炸和枪战的场面，玩家在游戏中扮演的是一个每天都在工厂检查设备的工程师，要求玩家通过智慧和观察来寻找生存之道，为生存而战！
  画质高，细节描述的非常棒，推荐一玩！
  缺点是读图有些慢。

23387758.review:
Dann fangen wir mal an. Wahrscheinlich bin ich einer der wenigen, aber ich hab mich schon immer für Bunker, Ruinen und alles, was irgendwie mechanisch aussieht interessiert. Als ich dann die Beschreibung dieses Spieles gesehen habe konnte ich also nicht anders, als es mir kaufen und ich war nicht enttäuscht.

Infra schafft es, dass man sich wirklich so fühlt, als würde man etwas Vergessenes neu entdecken. In diesem Bezug stimmt einfach alles. Das Leveldesign, der Sound und die Grafik (vielleicht nicht up-to-Date aber aufjedenfall mehr als passend) lassen den Spieler vollkommen in seiner Rolle aufgehen und ich war wirklich konstant dabei nach den kleinsten Details ausschau zu halten, die überall versteckt sind.

Ich für meinen Teil war an bestimmten Stellen (2. Chapter z.B.) so angespannt, dass mich wirklich ALLES erschreckt hat. Ich kann auch wirklich nicht sehen, warum hier 'walking Simulator' so oft als negativer Punkt aufgezählt hat. Dieses Spiel braucht nicht mehr, um das herüber zu bringen, was es herüber bringen will. Die Puzzle sind schlau und passend in das Level eingebaut und es gibt oft mehr als nur einen Weg durch besagtes Level.

Pros:
-Eine Welt, die man fast schon als 'Grimdark' bezeichnen könnte
-Durchdachtes Leveldesign
-Fesselnde Atmosphäre
-Optionale, aber sehr interessante Story

Cons:
-Voice Acting
-Steuerung könnte besser sein

Was dem Spiel fehlt ist Eindeutig die Möglichkeit seine geschossenen Bilder anzusehen, zu Ordnen und zum Puzzle lösen benutzen. (Oder einfach nur die Landschaft Fotografieren und sein Werk betrachten). Außerdem sind die Animationen und Synchronstimmen und das fehlen eines Spielermodels recht 'Immersion-breaking'.

Wer also auf der suche nach einem Spiel ist, in das er voll eintauchen kann, wer gerne Geheimnisse aufdeckt oder einfach gerne Erkundet ist mit Infra an genau der richtigen Stelle... Ich hoffe nur, dass die 2. Episode bald herauskommt...

23268680.review: Good game. Might be too passive for some, but to me it managed to capture the beauty of abandoned places.

23262554.review:
While INFRA has a unique atmosphere and the first challenges show promise of a different approach to puzzles, foundational flaws make the game unimmersive, tedious and aggravating. Scavenger hunts and repeat deaths are not fun.

You play as an infrastructural analyst, tasked to investigate reports of damage at various facilities. The game has you enter these facilities, explore them and then try to figure your way forward to the next area. Exploration has you documenting various types of damage, finding documents exposing multi-layer corruption, and finding secrets and easter eggs.

Advancing usually means a scavenger hunt to find a small card, key or a specific object hidden in some obscure place, or figuring out how to operate machinery by reading manuals and then running back and forth between buttons, levers, valves and computer screens. Sometimes parts of the machinery have been inexplicably removed and hidden, so that also means more scavenger hunts. There will be many dead ends with no importance, and some sections will be timed death traps that require foreknowledge of the area.

Dialogue isn't that great to begin with, but the voice acting is simply all-around terrible. Graphics feel somewhat outdated (partly due to Source engine), and the quality of  level design stretches from the fantastically lively places to the tediously barren levels. And at some point finding beer [i]everywhere[/i] starts to get annoying.

I had high hopes for the game when it appeared on Greenlight, but I can't recommend this.

23174102.review:
INFRA is a different type of game – a first-person exploratory puzzler. No guns – the only things you'll be shooting are pictures; minimal inventory – just your camera, flashlight, batteries for both, and whatever random bit of the environment you're lugging around at the moment, whether that be a fuse that belongs in a fusebox somewhere, a crate you'll need to cross a pool of electrified water, or an empty beer bottle that's just lying around, waiting to be smashed.

 
Infrastructure Isn’t Sexy

You play an engineer who works for a fictional Baltic country's infrastructure inspection service (in case you're wondering, the developers are based in Finland). Your job is to go out to inspect dams, highways, bridges – all the little things that make life easier, but could cause disasters if they break. And boy, do they ever break.

In a nice nod to just how things work in the real world (channeling John Oliver here), the nation's infrastructure – and the agency itself – is pretty blatantly underfunded. Even your starting office area is badly in need of repair, and only sparsely staffed. The workers hanging around complain about unsafe – but heavily used – tunnels that they refuse to drive through because they know just how bad they are.

The plot of the game kicks off with a typical, monotone office meeting (which, mercifully, you can skip), explaining where to go (a local abandoned dam system) so that you can gather photographic evidence of the repairs that need to be done, as well as doing patch jobs on whatever you can. Using your camera (or flashlight) drains batteries like crazy, but you can find plenty of them as you go along. The only downside is that there is no real way to tell how many batteries of each type you have left, aside from your character's comments when picking up fresh packs or installing a new set. The digital camera – which helpfully adjusts its viewfinder whenever you point it at something you need to photograph, has a battery meter; the flashlight just grows dimmer and dimmer to the point of uselessness, as its way of saying “Feed me!” The whole short battery lifespan thing is par for the course for a video game – but, obviously, they only drain when they are active (this includes looking around with the camera out).

Your secondary purpose, along the way, is to figure out why the place was abandoned in the first place – and you can even find some evidence pointing to this in your home office if you explore it thoroughly enough. It looks like a profound lack of funding might not be the only problem with this country.

 
Dam It

INFRA uses standard WASD for movement controls, E to interact, R to reload batteries, F to toggle the flashlight; jump, crouch, pickup/drop/throw – you know the drill. All fairly standard FPS-type controls. Spinning the mouse wheel toggles the camera, and clicking it zooms in or out. For better or for worse, there’s no HUD, and no inventory screen.

If you don't quite make a jump, you just get kicked back a few seconds of gameplay. They want you to play the game, not re-do ten minutes of running around every time you miss a jump by a few pixels. There are no enemies save for the environment itself – a few feet of water, most falls, etc. will one-shot kill you if you're not careful, along with the more obvious deathtraps such as the aforementioned electrified pools of water. For certain scripted, survivable falls, your character will have something to say about that, complete with some colorful language.

 
Graphics and Sound

The game is simply gorgeous at maxed visuals, even on a mid-range graphics card (GeForce 660). Old crumbling bricks and concrete, rust-covered metal, faded glass, and flowing water all contribute nicely to the atmosphere of the game, while providing an effective contrast to the relative sterility of your equally-in-need-of-repair home office. The dam and its environs feel abandoned and empty, even if most of the vehicles you find look brand new, and have been polished to a mirror shine!

The ambient noises that comprise much of the soundtrack accompany the visuals well – birds chirping out in the wilderness, winds rushing down deserted corridors, water dripping off of rusty pipes, etc.
[Eric Kei]

Summary
INFRA is a nice break from the run-of-the-mill first person games. They take a topic that most people find exceedingly dull, but with a touch of mystery, some entertaining gameplay mechanics, and excellent visuals, turn it into something worth sinking several hours into – and it's longer than you might think. A true exploration game.

Previously published on dlh.net -- Eric_Kei

http://www.dlh.net/en/reviews/2128/infra--pc-.html

23052957.review:
[h1]Niet voor iedereen, maar een goed gemaakt en interessant spel.[/h1]

In dit spel stap je in de schoenen van een 'structureel analyst', wij zouden het denk ik een werktuigbouwkundig ingenieur noemen, die in opdracht van zijn bedrijf een aantal gebouwen moet onderzoeken. Van deze gebouwen zijn geen of onvolledige onderhoudsrapporten gevonden en het vermoeden is dat het geld voor het onderhoud is weggesluisd en dat deze gebouwen (waaronder een waterkrachtcentrale) in een slechte bouwstaat verkeren. Jij gaat op pad met je digitale camera en zaklamp om foto's te maken van eventuele schade en de staat van deze gebouwen in kaart te brengen. Terwijl je hiermee bezig bent, ontdek je dat er bij de aankoop en latere verkoop van de bedrijven van wie de onderzochte gebouwen zijn schimmige spelletjes gespeeld zijn. Je ontdekt dit op de inmiddels gebruikelijke wijze: achtergelaten briefjes, aantekeningen, bandopnames en foto's. Veel van deze aanwijzingen zijn verstopt op moeilijk bereikbare plekken en je zult moeten klimmen, kruipen en allerhande puzzels moeten oplossen om het mysterie te ontrafelen en je weg te kunnen vervolgen. In tegenstelling tot veel andere spellen, hebben de ontwikkelaars hun best gedaan alles zo realistisch mogelijk te maken. De meeste puzzels bestaan uit het vinden van sleutels op moeilijk bereikbare plekken en in het aanpassen van de apparaten en systemen die je tegenkomt in de gebouwen. De puzzels voelen hierdoor niet kunstmatig aan, maar zijn op een logische manier in de omgeving verwerkt. Sommige achievements verdien je eenvoudig door de verschillende hoofdstukken uit te spelen, maar voor andere achievements zul je flink je best moeten doen. Ik voorzie dat ik het spel nog zeker een of twee keer zal moeten uitspelen om alles te vinden.

[i]De zwakke punten van het spel[/i]
- De stemmen zijn (grotendeels?) ingesproken door acteurs die Engels duidelijk niet als voertaal hebben. Het is niet tenenkrommend slecht, maar je hoort het wel meteen. Persoonlijk vind ik het niet zo erg, het verhaal is goed en de dialogen zijn geloofwaardig, maar sommige spelers zullen zich hieraan storen.
- geen beschrijving van de besturing met een controller, sommige acties worden gedurende het spel netjes aangegeven op het scherm, maar een overzicht (en de optie om knoppen aan te passen) zouden welkom zijn geweest
- digitale camera en zaklamp met beperkte gebruiksduur, batterijen zijn ruim genoeg voor handen, maar je moet ze na ongeveer 10 foto's of twee minuten gebruik van de zaklamp vervangen en dat is verre van realistisch, het voelt aan als een geforceerde poging om het spel spannender te maken (of om de claim dat je moet zien te overleven te rechtvaardigen)
- de ontwikkelaars noemen het een 'survival' spel, maar dat is enigszins overdreven. Ja, je kunt doodgaan door verdrinking, electrocutie, verstikking of een te grote val, maar verwacht niet dat je hout moet verzamelen voor een kampvuur en dat je paddestoelen moet eten om je gezondheid te herstellen en dat je zelf wapens moet maken of iets dergelijks. 
- geen mogelijkheid om het spel via het menu op te slaan. Wel zijn er regelmatige checkpoints en je kunt F6 en F9 voor quick save en quick load gebruiken. Toch vind ik het een punt van aandacht, omdat het spel uit verschillende hoofdstukken bestaat en als je voorbij in een hoofdstuk voorbij een bepaald punt komt dan wordt het deel wat je hebt voltooid afgesloten en je kunt er niet meer naar terug. En gezien de vele verborgen sleutels, briefjes enz. is dat een minpunt. Je kunt dit oplossen middels de F6 en F9 toetsen, maar aangezien ik met een controller speel, is dat onhandig
- je maakt foto's, maar je kunt ze niet terug zien, vooral jammer omdat ik soms zou willen dat ik foto's kon maken van de uitgebreide schema's die aan de muur hangen (t.b.v. een van de puzzels). In plaats daarvan houd ik weer ouderwets aantekeningen bij op een notitieblok.
- af en toe kom ik kleine bugs en glitches tegen, maar tot nu toe niets waardoor ik niet verder kon of een eerder spel moest laden
- ik heb een aantal puzzels niet kunnen oplossen, omdat ik aan een wiel had gedraaid of op een knop had gedrukt waardoor de puzzel in een niet-oplosbare toestand leek te zijn beland. Maar het kan ook zijn dat ik een deel van de puzzel heb gemist, er zit zoveel verborgen dat het me niets zou verbazen als ik stomweg op de verkeerde manier probeerde deze puzzels op te lossen. Het heeft me (tot nu toe) niet verhinderd om een hoofdstuk uit te spelen, maar ik heb hierdoor wel informatie gemist.
Bovenstaande punten zijn voor mij geen breekpunten (anders zou ik het spel niet aanbevelen), hooguit kleine irritaties. Tot nu toe vind ik het meest irritant dat ik soms gesloten deuren tegenkom waarvan onduidelijk is of je ze kunt openen. Van sommige deuren vond ik na verloop van tijd een sleutel of een mechaniek waarmee ik ze kon ontgrendelen, andere deuren heb ik (nog) niet kunnen openen, terwijl ik van sommige deuren bijna zeker weet dat ze open zouden moeten kunnen. 

[i]Wat ik erg goed vind aan het spel[/i]
- interessant verhaal (gebaseerd op ware gebeurtenissen)
- puzzels zijn lastig, maar niet onmogelijk, het vraagt vooral om goede observatie, goed nadenken en enig experimenteren. Elke keer dat ik dacht dat ik ergens niet verder kon, vond ik een tijdje later zelf de goede oplossing en dat geeft een gevoel van competentie
- mooie omgevingen, niet zo gedetailleerd als bijv. Ethan Carter, maar het komt een eind in de buurt. Alles ziet er ook uit alsof het echt zou kunnen bestaan. In alle gebouwen zijn toiletgroepen en kantines en dergelijke te vinden. Bureaus van verschillende medewerkers hebben ieder een eigen, unieke inrichting. Terwijl je in veel spellen ziet dat bureaus gewoon worden geknipt en geplakt. Ook vind je verschillende gebouwen bewijs dat er (tieners of krakers) zitten of hebben gezeten. Wat wel opvalt is dat veel voorwerpen zijn hergebruikt (zelfde stoelen, knoppenpanelen, bomen, bloemen, rotsen enz.) en bij sommige voorwerpen zijn relatief lage resolutie afbeeldingen gebruikt, terwijl andere voorwerpen scherpe en bijna fotorealistische afbeeldingen gebruiken. Door de aandacht waarmee de natuur, de gebouwen en elke afzonderlijke ruimte zijn ingericht, wordt dit niet storend. Maar het valt op een gegeven moment op dat je regelmatig dezelfde poster, koffiebeker, graffiti enz. tegen komt. 
- puzzels passen bij het gebouw waar je ze tegen komt. Puzzels worden ook goed afgewisseld, soms moet je een sleutel vinden op een onverwachte plek, soms moet je met kratten sjouwen en andere keren moet je een grote machine aan de praat zien te krijgen of de code van een cijferslot zien te vinden.
Voor het eerste spel van een kleine groep ontwikkelaars is het een hele prestatie en tot nu toe is de ervaring de moeite waard geweest (ik zit ongeveer op de helft). En daar komt nog bij dat je het tweede deel van het spel automatisch krijgt na aanschaf van het eerste deel, zodra het klaar is.

23027616.review:
(Forgive me if the formattings terrible i havent written a Steam review before)

Let me start by saying I really enjoyed INFRA, it wasnt what I was expecting (I dont really know what you could expect after reading you get to be a structural analyst in the first line of text but yeah...) but I felt it was a really rewarding and relaxing journey.

So what actually is it?

INFRA is a kind of mix between a game like Amnesia and Dear Esther, you get the puzzle elements from one, and the story elements/walking from the other (mostly the walking). I thought the puzzles were extremely well done personally, they dont have a sort of mad science feel that some other games like this have, its mostly about you controlling stuff to progress on and complete your job (which is to monitor how bad the spot is wrecked so you can begin fixing it).

I've noticed it had the tag of horror but I wouldn't really agree with that, I didnt come across anything that made me feel uneasy at all, it was just quite atmospheric throughout. By the way you dont get attacked by anything like in a survival horror game. I felt that was something I should mention because I was concerned about that throughout. 

The story is pretty decent to, the game tells the tale of an economic collapse of an entire region, and you get to experience how it progressed to where it was by looking through notes and areas that you experience when going through the game. I began by not really careing all too much and didnt pay that much attention to the newspaper articles littered through the world, but then towards the end I started to read through them and found them to be quite interesting, so my recommendation was if you get it do that from the start :).

This game has a great atmosphere too, in particular theres a section where you go into an abandoned steel factory and lose connection with the outside world, and it feels really earie which I guess explains the horror tag. The sound was done really well in this area too, mostly silent with a low bassy hum of I guess the old poweplant? 

Speaking about sound, I really liked the soundtrack for the game and I felt that it fit well with each section, so if you have a few extra pennies I'd say its worth buying it.

My time played shows roughly how long the game lasts, and I'd say its not bad for a small indie game, infact quite good. Theres also multiple collectables and stuff you can go back and do for the achievements giving you a reason to play it again, which you know, its always a positive. 

Bad Bits:

Although I really enjoyed my experience with INFRA theres a few points I think you should know: 

1. The voice acting at the start was pretty bad, the characters other than your own didnt feel genuine at all and the animations of the people were lacking quite a bit (but this goes away after about the first 15 mins or so, so dont worry about that too much). 

2. Its got quite a walking simulator feel to it, aside from the puzzles, and is more of a relaxing experience than an intense one. So thats something to watch out for if you don't really like those types of games.

Anyway to sum this up, I also had a crack at making a video review which you may want to check out to see what the gameplay is like and get my full view on it before you buy it:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=THlqNr-opzE

22996148.review:
If you like exploration or puzzle games you have to buy this one.
Pros:
-Excellent music (In my opinion)

-It doesn't have the best graphics but they look awesome.

-The athmosphere is great, it's complemented by the graphics and it's my favorite part of the game.

-The puzzles are ok, they are not very hard, and not very easy. Some of them are a bit boring, you have to search for a key or a fuse, so it gets boring after you spend 10 minutes searching for it.

-The story it's a good one. It's separated in three (3) chapters. It's pretty much straight forwards, BUT if you pay close attention you'll realize why everything is the way it is, and soon you'll see that there's a big conspiracy behind everything.

-The maps are great, they match the athmosphere perfectly.

-The developers are active with the game and help the community all the time in the forums. If someone is stuck they tell  that person clues to find the solution to a puzzle. If someone finds a bug. The developers fix it in the next update and the tell to that person a command to input and skip the section, so the player can continue playing. This should be and example of how to be a good developer team.
Cons:
-Voice acting, This is between con and pro, because it's, well... It does it's job. It sounds a bit forced but I ended up liking it.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

-Having finished the game already, it definetly was worth my money, I really loved the part 3. But that's because I am studying to work in these kinds of places, so it hits my spot. I'd say the length is 12-14 hours. Maybe 9 if you speed run it. I love the details of the game and I finished it 4 times just to take a look at the details. 
You'll realize the developers pay a lot of attention to details.
With a conspiracy that big, it's hard to fit the puzzle pieces without looking at the big picture.

This is definetly my kind of game. I wish I'd see more games like this. Nominated game for steam awards, I believe it deserves it.

22987990.review:
BugZy's Review: INFRA - Debris, debris everywhere

The following is my opinion.

In INFRA, you enter the world of a structural analyst, just another day at the extremely large and detailed office - and I say large and detailed because that is completely the case. About half of the building is unavailable to explore, but you can see through the many big windows that more than a lot of time and effort has gone into this building alone. The building is only a fraction of the game and it would already make up one of the best maps for an online FPS.

Anyway, your job turns from bad to worse when you go to visit and report deteriorating infrastructure. I will avoid spoiling any more of the game so you can experience it for yourself. Just expect to spend a lot of time exploring places that the people at Loiste didn't need to add, but added anyway, which made the game just that little bit more detailed and affected the overall amenity of the game in the long run.

The game can be compared to a not-so-scary version of Outlast, in that you are navigating dark areas with a camera. Unfortunately your camera doesn't have a built-in flashlight, so you carry one seperate (which if the developers had thought through, you would be able to smack some stuff with.) The camera and flashlight both have batteries that drain unbelievably fast though, so you must find some new ones lying around in convenient places. Not to worry, there are more than enough lying around!

As you can see, I am so far, very impressed with INFRA. It has some very meticulous developers and the environmental graphics are brilliant (the humans could use some more detail though, but the environment makes up for that.) The sound effects in the game make the game a bit eerie and - although it is a completely non-violent game - it does get a bit spooky (especially when you take a picture of something out of the ordinary, that sound caught me off guard a few times.)

The game plays nicely once you manage to load it up without crashing, Sometimes it crashes on launch, sometimes mid-game, sometimes when I'm trying to quit. No game is without problems, though.

Overall, the game is awesome and I would recommend it to anyone who likes exploration, attention to detail and/or taking photos.

I rate it 8/10 very detailed koalas.

22958437.review:
Ultimamente tenho experimentado um punhado de títulos de exploração, pejorativamente e injustamente chamados de "Walking Simulators", e que surpresa agradável foi o INFRA! Adorei a estrutura deste jogo. Você pode jogar de forma cadenciada e relaxante, o que permite explorar os cenários com calma. Definitivamente eu incorporei a profissão do personagem, que é uma espécie de engenheiro de estruturas e é munido de uma câmera. Como um zeloso inspetor estrutural, procuro registrar minunciosamente tudo que não está em ordem e que compromete a estrutura ou a segurança do local. Seguem alguns tópicos, positivos e negativos:

[u]Pontos Positivos:[/u]

+ Gráficos: INFRA é um jogo bastante bonito. Existem pormenores por todos os cenários, como lixo acumulado, sinais de velhice, goteiras e todo o tipo de bagunça. Infelizmente não tenho uma máquina muito potente, mas imagino que o game fica soberbo nas configuraçãos Ultra.

+ Ambientação: Este aspecto é mais subjetivo, mas eu definitivamente adoro os locais do jogo. Aparantemente ele se passa na Finlândia, e como sou suspeito em relação aos países escandinavos, fico enbasbacado admirando as paisagens externas.

+ Câmera: O recurso da câmera foi uma grande sacada da produtora. Como é opcional, quem não tiver paciência pode simplesmente ignora-la, mas eu o aconselho a tirar proveito deste gameplay e reservar um tempo para tirar umas fotos de danos ou documentos relevantes.

+ Exploração: Aproveite que não há monstros ou alienígenas te aporrinhando e explore os locais com calma. Os puzzles são adequados, no ponto certo. Não são nem muito fáceis e nem muito difíceis. 

[u]Pontos Negativos:[/u]

- Dublagem: Fiquei espantado com a dublagem horrorosa do personagem principal. Ele não tem um boa entonação, tem um timbre ruim e fala mecanicamente, sem emoção alguma. O game tem sons ambientes bem recriados, mas tenha certeza que você não vai querer ficar ouvindo o seu personagem.

- Baterias: Em INFRA é preciso procurar baterias para a sua câmera e lanterna. E procure mesmo, pois elas duram ridiculamente pouco. Após aproximadamente 15 fotos já é preciso trocar as baterias. Com a lanterna é a mesma coisa, e procure racionar o uso. Eu entendo que procurar novas baterias torna a exploração interessante, mas elas duram muito pouco e isso é bem chato.

Recomendo definitivamente o jogo. Para quem gosta de jogos cadenciados, com bons puzzles e exploração, INFRA é compra certa.

22824802.review:
Mein Favorit unter den Walking Sims. :) Spiel ist komplett in Englisch, ein paar Englischkenntnisse sind also erforderlich. Es gibt eingestreute Rätsel, die sich hauptsächlich um Maschinen und Elektrizität drehen, und alle in der Realität verankert sind. Mit Taschenlampe, Batterien müsse gefunden werden, und Kamera, auch hier müssen Batterien gefunden, geht man auf die Reise durch verschiedene technische Bauwerke, z.B. Stahlwerk, Kläranlage, etc.
Dabei fotografiert man alles was nicht in Ordnung ist, hauptsächlich Schäden an den Bauwerken und Maschinen, denn schließlich spielt man einen "Inspekteur". Dabei findet man im Laufe des langen Spiels auch den roten Faden, der sich eher unauffällig im Hintergrund hält.

Es gibt Zeitungen, Berichte, Notizen zu lesen, die einem die Story erzählen oder einfach nur Hinweise zu den Rätseln geben. Schlüssel müssen auch mal hier und da gefunden werden.
Oft gibt gibt es mehr als nur einen Weg durch ein Level, wobei der zusätzliche Weg zumeist mit einem Rätsel verbunden ist.

Das Spiel nutzt die Source-Engine die auch in Half Life 2 zum Einsatz kommt. Die Level sind schön gestaltet, detailliert und laden zum Erkunden ein. Die Soundkulisse passt, und die wenigen Musikstücke sind auch gut eingesetzt.

Es gibt zwei oder drei Action-Sequenzen, die aber relative einfach zu bewältigen sind. Das wäre auch meine einzige kleine Kritik an dem Spiel. Auf diese Action hätte man auch verzichten können.

Das Spiel ist Teil 1. Teil 2 befindet sich schon in Arbeit. Ca. 10 Stunden sollte man mit INFRA schon zu tun haben, was wesentlich länger ist als andere Vertreter des Genres.

22802614.review:
To be honest, when I bought INFRA, I really didn't know what would be involved.
Now, I know, And I can tell you, INFRA is more than a game. It's a real experience to master, an unexpected journey, a precious one.
I had no particular expectations when I started to play and very quickly I've been really impressed.
From the office, that warm cocoon you have to leave with your only "friends", your flashligh and your camera, to the very last dark tunnel you have to escape to.
The game brilliantly alternates between the great outdoors and shabby interiors, between quiet moments and those more agitated, between easy puzzles and those which will lead you gently but steadily to madness.
There's also the purpose to deeply involved the player, not only to follow a path, but to make it your own way.
The more you'll explore the faster you'll understand what, why and how you need to do it.
From here, the only usefull advice I can give to you : Keep your eyes fully opened and your brain fully prepared to really appreciate it.
Yes, INFRA is a masterpiece. Unique and scarce one.
Thanks Loiste Interactive for being more than just a company that wants to make money.

22641763.review:
Одна из худьших поделок на Source.
[list]
[*]Весь геймплей основан на нахождении 999 кнопочек на карте и нажимании их в определённой последовательности.
[*]Вам дан цифровик, но он совершенно бесполезен т.к. только умеет делать вид, что чёт сфотографировал и всё.
[*]Отвратительная реализация "реалистичного передвижения". Игрок практически с нулевой скоростью поднимается по лестницам, учитывая, что на некоторых картах надо сбегать от точки до точки раз эдак 100, то хочется просто закрыть игру и удалить как страшный сон.
[*]Вырвиглазная цветовая коррекция. Карты построены весьма криво, автору (ам) видать очень плохо удаётся природа. Ходишь как по  декорациям, всё плоское, не настоящее, не живое. Более менее удались некоторые помещения.
[*]Криворукое сохранение, выходите из игры и ваших сохранений как не бывало, сохранение происходит только после прохождения главы, а на это дело уходит туча времени. Видимо по мнению разрабов весело проходить повторно предыдущую главу.
[*]Начало игры просто ужасно, по офису ходят какие-то одинаковые мутанты, явно видны не сшитые полигоны, в местах стыков тела и рукавов у нпс явные щели. Главно надо догадаться, сходить куда-то на задний двор, залезть в самый тёмный угол и найти там маленькую железячку, без которой эта карта не закончится.
[*]Все двери открываются в сторону игрока, что опять же заставляет бросить игру.
[*]В игре напиханы неоправданно огромные текстуры в 4К без сжатия, в итоге игра весит почти 10 гигов, а на деле там ничего и нету, можно было обойтись, тем, что уже VALVe накопили за это время.
Например обычный грузовик, который встретится буквально 2 раза - 85мб и это только диффуз текстура и таких текстур на 4 гига. Движок взят от Alien Swarm, движок поддерживает vpk, но видимо это лень было использовать. Все файлы лежат по папкам, из-за чего игра и карты грузятся оооочень долго. А так-же игра сжирает огромное кол-во опреативной памяти из-за бесполезных текстур.
[/list]
Короче говоря: берите, только если вам хочется ипать свои мозги кривыми головоломками без подсказок.
Я бы рад вернуть за неё деньги, но наиграно уже 6 часов, а пройдено 2.5 главы из-за кривых сохранений и нелогичности головоломок.

22639630.review:
Not knowing really what to expect, the premise immediately hooked me in that I genuinely cared about my job as a structural engineer going out into the countryside and city of Stalburg.  I was welcomed with beautiful hiking, urban exploration, nature, and fascinating infrastructure and overall care taken by the designers, programmers, and artists of this wonderful Finnish gem.

All that would have been enough, but included are elements of intrigue, intense enviromental action, and a sense that my presence in the world is having long-lasting effects for its infrastructure!

The ending of Part 1 was very abrupt for me, but Part 1 is certainly lengthy and quite varied! I simply can't wait for more of this game and more similar games to come from Loiste Interactive!

22628516.review:
First of all, the game is beautiful, yet it doesn't rquire a high-end machine to max out. Dont get me wrong, the graphics arent photorealistic - they are just very well crafted in terms of level design and setting an ambience. Its not just a couple of very detailed setpieces with bland areas in between, all environments in INFRA have been crafted with the same attention to detail. INFRA is truly a level designer's game.

The puzzles are truly challenging if you want to do them properly, but the game also allows you to progress without finishing them. This creates a very rewarding game that, at the same time, can be completed by nearly anyone.

The story isnt really that deep, in fact sometimes it feels like a portal rip-off, but everything is made up by the phenomenal atmosphere the game offers. Even with the shortcomings regarding the main story, I found the game very immersive.

Is INFRA a walking simulator? Not really. The environment interaction in infra is deep, and always conected with the core puzzle gameplay. This means the walking around and enjoying the visuals isnt its own goal, but rather forms a solid puzzle solving experience with plenty of eye candy.

All in all, a very enjoyable experience.

22573269.review:
I was expecting a 4-hour game at best, but instead I got 18 hours of enjoyable exploration and puzzle solving set entirely in Finland, as it should be used more as a setting and not just for sports games. And that's just Part 1. I can't imagine how many more locations are in store in Part 2, which will be a free update, when I've already experienced the length of at least two modern FPS games for €15. Not only is it a refreshing change of setting from your usual New Yorks or what have you, though any city would work here, it's also inspired by a documentary about deteriorating infrastructure. That fact alone fills me with confidence that games as an art form is in safe hands. It's a fascinating choice of subject matter for a developer's first game and not in any way presented through a prism of science fiction or a military conflict, which is usually the choice for first-person games set in crumbling cities.

Instead of having a decaying city as a backdrop, it's a character of the story. A victim of neglect, rivaling companies and corruption. You're tasked with surveying the structural damage of the city of Stalburg by taking photos of the damage. Finding documents and tapes people have left behind, you start to piece together where it all went haywire. You work your way through a maze of different locations, each of them detailed to the point of being believable, but not impressive by standards available to those with a huge budget. This being a crowd-funded game however, the scope and level of detail achieved here is shocking for a team of just 6 people, according to the credits.

INFRA removes the guns, the aliens or bad guys with guns and you're left with elements that every great FPS relies on: exploration, environmental storytelling, quiet moments, puzzle solving, dealing with obstacles, etc. It's a game of valves, switches, key cards, buttons, turning it off, turning it on, reading notes and instructions to operate machinery and I loved every minute of it. You can find most of these in every notable FPS since the days of DOOM. The reason I'm emphasizing these is because the devs have honestly described what their game is about. It's not overburdened by pointless distractions that only create the illusion of immediacy and importance. What you're doing here is important in and of itself. The game sends a strong message of being responsible with the world around you, which is, among all these hugely expensive and ultimately pointless games, thoroughly heartwarming and commendable. Not to mention rare.

Couple of moments where I couldn't figure out how to progress, so I consulted a video walkthrough, but I'm more bummed about the the stuff I didn't know how to repair. You're stuck between analyzing and trying to leave a place in a better shape than it was, but many of the bigger puzzles tied to achievements I just couldn't figure out, so grudgingly I had to move on. Thankfully there are no easy-to-use guides out there yet, so you can actually enjoy the puzzles as opposed to following a step-by-step guide on how to restore the functions of all these different facilities. There is damage, or scripted moments, that's unavoidable, but instinctively you try to be responsible where you can. These places have been abandoned, reminiscent of Pripyat, but the machinery still has life left in it, which continue to do damage.

The overall aesthetic reminded me of STALKER meets Half-Life 2, so a big thank you for Loiste Interactive in filling a gap that certain developers have failed to do for too long. To crawl through vents and solve puzzles is not to be underestimated, guns or no guns. While I eventually gave up on reading newspapers or longer notes, towards the end, I'm very much interested in how the story will progress in Part 2 and I look forward to taking more photos and solving puzzles. Somehow I've managed to ignore the elephant in the room. The voice acting of the player character is atrocious, but it steadily grows on you at a snail's pace, cos it's just so bad that it becomes almost cute. There is a lack of polish here, but that didn't stop Shadow of Chernobyl in becoming one of the best games of all time. You have to let a few things slide in order to get something special out there and that's fine, cos it's important that we get to play this in its current form than not at all.

22520970.review:
I keep trying to write a review for this game but I keep starting again. I can't really put into writing what this game is. 

What I can say is; is that [b]I really like it[/b]. Having now played through the entire game from start to finish I felt the need to recommend it. 

In short, you walk around abandoned buildings, tunnels and facilities and solve puzzles in order to progress. You are either the luckiest person in the world or the unluckiest, because everything seems to collapse or explode around you but you always just about find a way to survive. 

But don't just think this is an abandoned building sight-seeing tour, oh no. The city is full of corruption and scandals that have lead to the neglect, deterioration and collapse of most of the city. 

The game looks good and generally runs well as well (It's a Source game at it's core, so most PCs should run it). Small parts towards the end of the game run slightly worse though [i](and there may currently be a memory leak/bug, as the game started to chug after 3/4 hours running straight during Act 1. Restarting the game fixed it)[/i]. 

But overall, it looks great, has an intriguing story behind it, and has a good selection of challenging but not [i]"make you want to smash your head against the monitor before jumping from your window"[/i] challenging puzzles.

I think the game is around 14hrs long, but this will vary largely depending on how much you explore and how terrible you are at some of the puzzles.

TL;DR - Great game for puzzle-lovers and world-explorers alike.

22357195.review:
[h1]あらすじ[/h1]
いつものようにインフラ施設の調査に派遣された主人公。事前情報も殆ど無い中調査を始めるが、なぜかどの施設も破棄されていた。社員の残した情報から浮かび上がる一人の人物の名と破産や買収の文字。警察や知事すら金で懐柔され、誰も事態に対処しないまま、都市は少しずつ崩壊していく……

[h1]ゲーム概要[/h1]
カメラ片手に施設を探索しながら修繕していくゲーム。
パズル自体は簡単なものが多いが、いかんせんノーヒントが多く装置の挙動を理解するのに苦労した。施設内部はよく作りこまれており探索が非常に楽しい。
ストーリーはあまり語られず、散在するドキュメント類からバックグラウンドを把握することになる。工場勤務の苦労がうかがえる。

[h1]バグ[/h1]
ロード中やメニュー画面でのクラッシュが多い。自分はSource engineのOutOfMemoryバグに遭遇して何度もロードし直すはめになった。
開発者曰く現在ではほとんど修正済みでレアなバグの対策中らしいのであまり心配はいらないかも。

[h1]総評[/h1]
ヒントはもう少し必要な気もするが、パズルの完成度は高く現実的なアドベンチャーを求めている人におすすめ。またインフラ施設も良く出来ているので無人の施設探索が好きな人も楽しめると思う。

INFRAは元々Indiegogoで出資を募っていたが、目標額に達せず前半と後半の2パートに分けて販売されることになった。今作はその前半部分。なので気になる人は後半が販売されてからまとめて買う方がいいかもしれない。
かなり中途半端に終わるので。

22305143.review: Really good game. I can just recommend to spend 15$ on this

22276922.review:
INFRA is a linear, story-driven adventure with an impressively well-realized world and engaging puzzles that are esoteric but not aggravatingly so.

Let's start with the world. INFRA is packed full of little details. It definitely rewards you for exploring and being observant. These rewards range from simple easter eggs to shortcuts. Puzzles in INFRA can have multiple solutions. You can get to the other side of a door by cunning navigation or clever circumventing. Because of these multiple routes, there are many offshoots (not complete branches because they connect back to the trunk quickly) that make the game feel organic and immersive. This game is definitely replayable as you will miss things the first time through.

Let's talk about the bad a little bit. So while on the whole, I thoroughly enjoy the puzzles in this game, they don't scale well. What I mean by this is that rather than having puzzles that get trickier as you progress through the game, the puzzles get harder to solve because the pieces become hidden. My favorite part of putting together a puzzle isn't the part where I have to dig in the couch cushions because I think I lost a piece. So while this can make simple things take longer it does have the upside of forcing you to explore the world more and none of the pieces were ever hidden in a way that I thought was unfair.

On the balance, the experience and mystery of this game significantly outweighs the frustrations of having wasted an hour because you didn't look behind a door or in a box.

My playthrough: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLL5JEFvVpx9oRUnwXp-tzlYvT6ea990wS

22104853.review:
INFRA is not my usual type of game - I normally stick to RTS titles. Yet the concept of walking through dilapadated ruins looking for dangerous cracks and things out of place sucked me in, and I'm very glad it did! Having played through Part 1 (Part 2 is due later and will not be DLC but an integral part of the game, which will rise in price when it is released, so buying now may save you!) I would say that my favourite part of INFRA is the incredible atmosphere the game manages to create. An effective mix of impressive visuals and ambient effects bring to life the game's juxtaposition of the natural and artificial landscapes - so you'll emerge from a tunnel to see the decaying entrace behind is encrusted in trees and plants just as a slightly haunting tune plays, giving a pleasantly melancholy feeling. 

The game puzzles are nice and varied, with clever use of the same elements to prevent everything from feeling too 'samey'. The game plot appears threadbare at first, but as the game progresses you can find out a lot more - nothing is presented explicitly, but if you piece together the scattered documents you find along the game you can put it all together, culminating in the final setpiece which sets the game up nicely for Part 2. The game has pretty good replay value, with a good mix of hidden achievements and collectibles (e.g. when going off the game path to some inaccessible place you'll sometimes find a geocache). After finishing my first playthrough I really want to go through again and find every little detail! Overall, INFRA is a steal for its price - I'd thoroughly recommend it

22060122.review:
Took about 14 hours to complete, at first I thought it was broken but the black load screens just seem to take ages and the white load circle doesn't move. Once i got passed that and into the game it looked crisp and well drawn, the voice actors are pretty bad but you don't get much after the first office section. A few phone calls to your boss and the funny "That's XX packs of batteries for the camera/torch"

There are enough batteries to fuel both the camera and the torch but it's often hard to know what to photograph, documents and clearly damaged areas but some things I snapped seemed to make no difference. Similarly some things I did in the game had no real purpose.

The game progressed nicely through woodland, into a dam then a logging factory then into a tunnel system. I rode an underground river on a raft that would capsize if it even brushed the rocky sides, that took a few tries to complete, mainly because I am an incompetant mariner :)

A few scary moments like the roof collapsing and the fire in a later level but nothing too dramatic unless you are claustrophobic or like me, scared of heights. The tower section of the old steelworks was scarilly high and my bottom was twitching as I stumbled up the rickety iron steps with wind turbines alongside me and the ground a long way down. The view of the city though was astonishing from up there and talking about the steelworks, It was huge! The scope of the buildings is very believable, you really feel like you are inside an old factory.

[spoiler]The ending was slightly disappointing because it just stopped and the credits rolled but then it said, continued in Infra 2 so...have to wait to continue but will definately buy it. [/spoiler]

22033417.review:

21996945.review:
[i]"Take a camera and a flashlight and get into a survival adventure full of puzzles you will need to solve. Go ahead and survive"[/i]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
I love graphic adventures, especially those who makes you think what's going on. There's a scent of danger here and you need to solve what's going on in that old facility. A great game with a great display and visuals. The puzzles are really difficult, maybe not all of them but get away of the danger, and don't forget your job, take those pics for the boss.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
It's quite easy. Go to your office and forget those boring morning debriefs. You have a work to do. Take the camera, flashlights and all things you gonna need in an old facility to solve the mystery. And the puzzles. You are a structural analyst, in the middle of a routine mission but things get complicated. I promise.

Don't forget to pick up for batteries! You gonna need for the camera and don't use it a lot. If you enter a place just use it once, take the picture if you need and turn it off, just to save batteries, and the flashlight. You will listen a sound when the appropriate picture is taken, take that into account.

Here the puzzles are very logic so think. Use your head, that gonna help you to continue your mission. Use your eyes too, there are keys or objects you gonna need to use. Don't forget to visit every corner of the "map". I always do that, you never know what to find.

We can forget about the music here, except in the car radio. In real life, we don't have music everywhere. But the ambience sounds are amazing, the birds, the wind, everything. Also, the voice interpretations are just great.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Very realistic adventure
+ Great sound effect
+ Intelligent puzzles
+ Great visual and display
+ Good story

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Sometimes you can feel frustrated if you don't pass the puzzle
- No gamma corrector. Adding one would be interesting.

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
This is an amazing game with a lot of puzzles, realistic ones you have to solve. I really recommend this game if you like that mix of a good graphic adventure, logic puzzles, and survival. Ah, don't forget the batteries.

[b]Rating:8.5/10[/b]

This review was submitted for [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/elitegives]Elite Giveaways[/url], check us out for more reviews ranging from Indie games to AAA games.

21988009.review:
[b]2016/09/29[/b]
[b]Part2公開に伴い、内容を補強しました[/b]

[h1]ゲーム概略[/h1]

ヘルメット、懐中電灯、そしてカメラを持って施設を点検して周るゲームです。
探検して周る、とは言いますが、実際にはパズルと言ったほうが的確かもしれません。

周る施設は多数あり、水力発電所やダム、木材加工場など枚挙に暇がありません。
プレイ時間はざっと10時間強（私は14時間でクリアしました）ですが、じっくりやろうと思えばあと4時間くらいは平気で伸びていくでしょう。


プレイヤーはカメラと懐中電灯を使い、施設を点検して周ります。
施設は相互に連絡している為、1施設終われば必ずしも次のチャプター、等というわけではなく、歩き進めることでどんどん進んでいくシステムとなっています。
一部では戻ることも可能です。
（但しまた一部の施設は一方通行で戻ることができない場合があります。）


点検の際、問題がある箇所は直し、また報告すべき事項がある場合には写真を撮ることがこのゲームの目的です。
明らかな破損などが写真の目的となりますが、ストーリーを示す文献等も写真に撮る意味があるようです。
（やらなければいけない訳ではないので、必ずしも必要とは限りませんが。）



[h1]細かい私感[/h1]

『おすすめするか、おすすめしないか？』と聞かれたら正直微妙ですが、わたしは[b]『おすすめする』[/b]、に1票入れておきます。


　[h1]評価点[/h1]
[list]
　[*]ダイナミックな自然。
　[*]精細に作りこまれた施設群。
　[*]実在品をモデルにしていると思われる小物類。
　　→アラ探しをしようにもこの辺りでは中々欠点が見つかりません。
　　非常に完成度が高いです。
　　→もしかしたら開発陣に施設建設等の経験者が居るのかも……？
　[*]実際に探索をしているかのような環境音。
　[*]場面に即した、臨場感溢れる音楽[b]（サウンドトラックのご購入も是非ご検討下さい！）[/b]。

　[*]実際に起きそうな現象・環境の変化・施設の扱われ方の表現。
　[*]濃厚なバックストーリー。
　　→手がかりの品物を読み解くことで理解できます。英語スキルか翻訳サービスのご準備を！

　[*]複雑怪奇極まる謎解き要素。
　　→謎解きの種類は結構多めです。

　[*]時間制限のある謎解きは少なめ。
　　→ゆっくり落ち着いて考えられます。
　　→一方時間制限ありの方は死にゲー区間です。回数を重ねて対策を立てましょう。
[/list]

本を読むような感覚で、かつ同時に美しい施設群の探索、そしてパズルも一緒に、そんな感じに構えてプレイするととても面白いゲームです。
中々こういったゲームがないだけに新鮮でもあります。
また、巨大なインフラ施設、機械、廃墟の類がお好きな方にも是非オススメです。


　[h1]欠点[/h1]

ただ一方でおすすめかの判断に迷う部分もあるということで……[b]正直微妙、と言うに値する欠点は大きいです。[/b]
しかもゲーム性に関わる部分ばかりに。


[list]
　[*][b]全部英語。攻略の手がかりも全部です。多少は英語ができないと苦労します。[/b]
　　→あるいは日本語化の到着を期待しましょう……。
　　→英語が出来ない方は諦めましょう。あるいは手元に迅速に使える翻訳アプリ等のご準備を。

　[*]いきなり起動しない/メニュー画面を出せない不具合
　　→数件報告があるだけなので、多くの人には起こらないでしょう。
　　→私には起きましたけどね……。
　[*]環境によっては酷いことになるローディング。
　[*]難しくてもヒントが殆どない謎解き。
　　→どうしても分からない場面では詰みます。諦めて先人の動画等を見ましょう。
　[*]『このスイッチを動かすとどれが動くのか』が分からない。
　　→謎解きだから仕方ない部分があるにしても酷すぎます。
　[*]スペランカーばりに貧弱な主人公。
　　→こんな段差も登れないのか！と苛立つこと請け合いです。
　[*]障害物へのよじ登り動作及びスプリント挙動が酷い。
　　→思ったように動けずイライラすることがあります。
　　→結構マシになりました。
　[*]次の段階への突破口となる唯一の手がかりがとても見つけにくい。
　[*]開けるのか開けないのか分かりにくいドア。
　　→開かないのが正解ということも結構あります。つまり行き止まり。
　[*](ネタバレ有り)[spoiler]余りにも救いようが無さ過ぎる、無慈悲で唐突な終わり方。
　　そりゃねえぜ！とPC前で叫びました。[/spoiler]
　　→[spoiler]続編部分が今度出るらしいので、そっちに期待ですね……。[/spoiler]
[/list]



[h1]総評[/h1]
欠点も多いゲームですが、個人的にはそれを補って余りあるゲームの雰囲気、重厚なストーリー、パズル性を鑑みてオススメとしておきます。
インフラ施設・廃墟探索ゲームとしては非常に出来がよろしいですが、[b] "ゲーム" としての操作性等の部分には難ありですので、そこを気にされる方にはおすすめできません。[/b]

Part2をプレイし終わってみると、操作性もだいぶ改善されたように感じられます。
謎解き要素も深まったので、廃墟や公共施設大好きな方ではなくても、
パズルやアドベンチャーが好きなら十分に挑む価値があると考えます。

一方で、せっかくPart1で見せつけられた美しい、息を呑むような退廃（？）美は、
Part2では地下区間が大幅に増大した為に機会を減らしてしまったように感じられます。
廃墟や公共土木が大好きな方にとっては、Part2はやや残念な感じに仕上がったかもしれません。


[h1]微細な補筆事項[/h1]
[list]
　[*]暗闇をぶっ続けで歩かされる箇所が多数あります。画面を明るくするご準備を。
　[*]制作陣の "お遊び" あるいはバックストーリー関連と思われる小ネタも多いです（中には即死確定ルートにあるものもありますが……）。
　　→（同関連では怖いのが苦手な方には
　　　　少しオススメできない箇所があります。
　　　　夜中にひとりでやっていた
　　　　私はかなりビビりました。）
　[*]Part1が終わり、Part2をこれからプレイされる方へ:
　　→[spoiler]スペシャルで！！なコーヒーは、
　　　　怖い事象が嫌いなら『絶対に』飲まないこと。
　　　　私は見てしまった。[/spoiler]
　[*]クリアした人向け:
　　→[spoiler]Part2が出たと聞いて、生きてた！やった！と思ったのに……
　　[b]またか！！[/b][/spoiler]
[/list]



[b]これからINFRA点検に向かわれる皆さん！[/b]

[b]ご安全に！[/b]
