21944676.review:
INFRA.
Це гра, перші години котрої я просто ходив і милувався довкіллям!
Все довкола настільки атмосферно зроблено, і разом з чудовим звуковим супроводом, просто занурюють у гру!
Але попри чудову візуальну складову (котра не є революційною, просто справді якісно подана) Атмосферний звуковий супровід, та цікавий сюжет, котрий ще й самому потрібно знайти (що є безперечно перевагою) це ще й платформер! Так справді, є сцени де ми повинні перестрибувати перешкоди сомотужки сворюючи платформи, і це виглядає ще й логічно в сетингу гри! Мені справді дуже сподобалась гра, і як маленька інді студія поєднала різні ідеї в чось справді цікве!

Переваги гри:
Чудова візуальна складова
Атмосферний звуковий супровід
Цікаий і актуальний сюжет
Загадки котрі є частиною довкілля
Нелінійність, до нових локацій і сюжетних елементів можна прийти різними шляхами
Цікаві гейм-дизайнерські рішення, наприклад камера (на котру ми повинні фотографувати сюжетні елементи, але котра має заряд батареї, і варто справді пошукати важливі речі!)

Мінуси гри:
Анімація персонажів (балувані ми захватом рухів...)
Озвучення персонажів (воно не є жахливе, просто не є професійне)

Однозначно рекомендую спробувати гру! Думаю ви теж будете приємно здивовані!

21936335.review:
[b]INFRA[/b] is a first person puzzle adventure game with a very mysterious tone to it. While some may call it a “walking simulator”, I personally disagree, most of all due to the fact that INFRA allows you to take different routes and solve puzzles in different ways. 

First off, it is necessary to say that at the moment only Part 1 of the game is available. The developers are already hard at work on Part 2 but, as of now, there is no estimated release date and the first part ends somewhat abruptly.

I was really surprised as I began to play this, that right from the start the game doesn’t hold your hand. Even though it is a linear game, you are able to explore your surroundings within certain limits. The game also doesn’t give you an objective so sometimes you might have a hard time figuring out what exactly you have to do or where you need to go. That said, even though you’ll encounter multiple puzzles, they are not mandatory but they might give you access to documents that can provide you with some background information on certain events that could potentially shed some light on the mystery you’re trying to solve. 

[h1]Story:[/h1]
You play as Mark, a structural analyst that is sent on a job to survey some old structures for potential degradation. What begins as just another day at work, quickly turns into a series of events that test his dexterity and resilience.

 At the beginning you’ll most likely find yourself lost and with no idea of what is going on but slowly throughout the game you’ll find clues that will reveal why these events are taking place and who is responsible for them. This was one of the reasons why I ended up exploring a lot and looking for as many documents and audio logs as I could. The world surrounding you seems so mysterious at first but you’ll gradually get to know the city past, its history, how it became an industrial power and what led to its demise.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
INFRA mechanics will be explained to you very early on and they are really simple but yet, they add a whole other layer to the game. The most important one is your camera. You can use it to photograph evidence of structural damage and documents that contain information relevant to your case. Assuming you’re actually interested and immersed in the world, this mechanic adds a lot to the game. I often found myself looking at every single structure I came across looking for damage, and still, I only found around 50% of the evidence in the game. 

One other mechanic that also plays a huge role is climbing. You can climb any object, assuming it is not very high, by just getting closer to it and jumping. Of course you can also jump in the “normal way” like in most first person games and this will also allow you to overcome some of the deadly traps that await you.

The puzzles in INFRA are varied but most of them involve activating switches or finding missing electrical components. Some of them are very easy and its answer will be obvious you right from the start. Others however, left me going back and forth on the level looking for hints and activating several switches in order to get them right which sometimes was rather tedious, especially on larger levels.

[h1]Visuals & sound:[/h1]
One thing that became pretty clear for me since the very start, was the fact that the voice acting is very subpar. This kind of voice acting combined with the lack of dialogue didn’t leave a lot of room to get attached to the main character.

Still, the game has great sound design with background noises and overall the music is pretty great as well. While the graphics close on are somewhat dated, from a reasonable distance they allow for quite the scenery. You’ll be exploring gorgeous open door environments, dark tunnels and abandoned buildings. Each of these places has its own unique markings, either it’s an old dam, an ancient tunnel or an abandoned industrial complex from the early 1900’s which make the game world feel a lot more real. All these aspects combined, provide for an amazing and relaxing experience

[h1]Complaints:[/h1]
- Loading times can take up to 30-40 seconds
- I experienced some framerate variations (even though I’m way above the recommended system specs), one second I’d have over 100 fps and the next moment it would dip down to the 40s and sometimes even lower
- The game auto-saves but there is also an option for manual saving. The problem I have with this is that you have 4 different save slots but it easily gets very confusing which save is which because the game gives you no indication other than “Save Slot 1”, “Save Slot 2”, etc.

[h1]Final thoughts:[/h1]

Even though only Part 1 is available, INFRA is well worth your time. It is a mysterious and engaging experience that conveys the story by narrative means other than dialogue. It has its relaxing and tense moments and, most importantly, it lets the player choose if they just want to storm through the scenarios or explore them meticulously looking for clues of the towns past and the whole mystery surrounding this structural degradation. I highly recommend INFRA to any fans of adventure or mystery games or to people who are looking to enjoy a nice and relaxing scenery.

21881590.review:
INFRA is a mixture of walking simulator and puzzle game.  On the outside looking in a person may shrug and think to themselves, another walker, ugh!!!  (in walker I mean Walking Simulator not the walking dead silly goose).  While this game isn't your typical walking simulator.  The scenery is beautiful, the puzzles can be quite challenging, the game is billed as the first part of a larger series of games, with the sequel set to release sometime in the "near" future..  If you go into the game expecting to whip out your arm cannon, or unload your boom stick, or even blast away creepy crawling monsters you'll be disappointed, no weapons, violence or monsters exist in INFRA, but you will get an amazing experience and a good story, told through various memo's notes, and character dialog. 

[b] Tech Issue[/b]
I had a few technical issues with my main computer, which was far above what the recommended specs are, and the game crashed to desktop when pushing play, white graphics in doorways, and a few other minor graphical issues.  I could get the game working but typically the moment it had to load, between stages etc, it would crash to desktop and require more tinkering to work.  I did however manage to play the game on my older PC which was barely above the minimum recommendations and it worked flawlessly and looked beautiful  I used every conceivable work around I could think of in order to get the game working on my updated computer but nothing would do the trick for long.  With that said, I'm not sure if it was the game or my computer which caused the issue, so I just wanted to put in here my experience.  

[b]The Story[/b]

You start the game as a man named Mark, he's currently sitting in on a board meeting, the "boss" goes through the specifics of what is required of Mark and his fellow teammates (although you're flying solo this time pal).  The basic story is Mark needs to visit a location and document damages to the structure, while at the same time keeping an eye out for documents which can help explain what brought about the demise of the crumbling buildings and town.   Sounds easy enough, after the meeting which is a 6 to 9 minute affair, you're tasked with searching out supplies, "getting some new markers" and collecting the car keys to drive yourself over to your eventual destination.  What follows is a relatively uninspired trip through an office.. Unfortunately if these guys are "structural" anything, they haven't done a good job as their building has many technical issues, and the elevator can only travel between a few floors...   ANYWAY, after getting your supplies (minus the markers... aww) you make your way to the parking Garage...  after that it's onward to your destination, for puzzles, walking, and possible even a few deaths..  (I totally suggest the moment you get out of truck, head to the left and take a dip in the water.. so warm it's awesome..  sike.. if you do that you're totally gonna die, did I say the game was a swimming simulator?)   From this point on you search around looking for clues, looking for batteries and broken structures to photograph. 

[b]Pros:[/b]
Beautiful scenery, 
Can be quite challenging to spot the structure issues.
The lands are fairly large and interesting
Doesn't hold your hand... (you won't find no glowing yellow streams in this one)
Puzzles can be rather difficult to figure out

[b]Cons:[/b]
Puzzles can be stupidly easy (although the easy puzzles are few and far between)
Technical issues (may have been my computer?)
Voice acting (the voice acting is like something out of the Playstation 1 era)
Total lack of direction or explanation of what your goal is (it's ok to not hold your hand, but at the very least give some idea of what is required to move onto the next portion of the state)
Backtracking (goes hand in hand with the above mentioned con)
Loading times can be upwards of a minute (this could be my computer as it had other issues with the game)
Some clipping issues, which can cause you to get stuck

[b]Recommendation[/b]
While I had a few issues with my computer it did sour me a bit, I understand it was probably something on my end rather than the game's end, so I set that aside and will recommend the game based on the merits..  Unlike many of the other Walking Simulators out there, this game actually did a good job of getting the atmosphere right.  The puzzles are challenging for the most part and the scenery is absolutely beautiful.  If you go along and photograph the various documents the story will unfold and as the story unfolds you'll see a grim picture of what happens when a towns infrastructure begins to erode away.

21878305.review:
[h1]If you want an episodically adult adventure, with puzzles, platforming and no gore, you probably need this game.[/h1]
First of all I have to say that this game is pretty good and deserve an upvote more. It has a very nice graphic, a good background sound, nice gameplay and a decent story. Everything, a good game needed. 

The game starts in a conference room where you wait for your boss and some work colleagues, they talk about work and what to do in future and you have to click some “PowerPoint”.  Then you get your mission. 

Go to a dam in a ghost town, documenting everything is broken or wrong and find documents, so far so good, first I search for my office to get my stuff I really need (flashlight, camera, helmet), as I found it I see, oh nice the boss gave me the new car. So I go throw the bureau and find all the things. That is how the game is all the time only in little.  Now I have to find the garage in basement, everything is broken, oh my god, go down the stairs, use the elevator, find the door key…ten minutes later…get into the car. (Short sequence) Get out of the car and the game starts finally. There I can make some pictures and I hear a gentle ringing (sound if you found something what broken or wrong). There are some items to collect but not many, batteries for flashlight and cam and the keyitems like keys, boltcutter etc. You can move some items like crates, in some situations its really necessary. The puzzles are mostly logical and aren’t hard, sometimes you will run in circles to search for the solution.

This game has no GUI, no inventory, no journal and no hints. If you collect or use batteries the character say how many packs left. This kind of style is OK for me. BTW save you batteries for later game, you will need it.

Graphic is very good, not an eye-catcher but still good. Environment and buildings very nice created. 

The price for the game is good, not pricy and there will be added more content.

Game: 8/10
Graphic: 8/10
Sound: 9/10

21853507.review:
Saw some gameplay video of Infra pre-release and I really liked the way everything was modeled very lifelike and with understanding of what to include in details and what to dismiss as irrelevant.
I decided to buy the game and found it much to my liking.

If you enjoy puzzle games in the sense of walking around, picking up stuff and solving puzzles, then this game is a good choice.

21840292.review:
Ever driven by a few abandoned factories, and said to yourself that it would be cool to take a look inside? I've done that. I most likely would have never known about this game if it wasn't for the steam coupon I had from leveling up my account. $5 for this game? I'll try it out. I'm glad I did.

First off, I want to say that a lot of effort went into making this game. You can tell. While there might be an overuse of the "locked door senario" to keep the areas to an easy semi-liniar path, there were some areas where I felt I was really there exploring it.

Some advice. Turn the Gamma up, or you aren't going to see the puzzles in some spots. Took me a while to figure out what I was doing wrong. Also, save frequently, just in case you encounter a very unusual glitch (like me when I raft rode and got stuck in a game-over loop).

Pros:
Great Maps
Some Great Puzzles
Great Idea (Not the typical action game)
There's more to come (Ep 2 free for people that buy part 1)

Cons:
Some puzzles were overly finiky
A few bugs (Most notably the missing valve in one part (fixed in update), and the raft riding part where it auto saved me to a point where I was stuck in a game over loop. Had to reload a save from before that.)
Thought the main character was suicidal. No joke. Had a hard time beleiving that this person was sane after seeing how he has no reguard for his personal well-being.

Overall, great game, and can't wait for Episode 2. Thumbs UP!!

21826556.review:
Este juego me ha encantado, a pesar de que aún no esta 100% terminado, y tiene alguno que otro bug.

Pero este juego tiene las atmósferas más impresionantes que he sentido en un videojuego. Es como si de verdad estuviera en una ciudad que se cae a pedazos. Incluso se puede sentir el peligro y el miedo de entrar a algunas partes.
No hay monstruos ni terroristas armados que debas enfrentarte, solo concreto que se desarma y se derriba, y tu propia mente.
El leer los documentos que aparecen en los mapas, ver esos detalles que se pueden observar en esos paisajes, es posible armar una historia de cómo todo eso que se ve en pantalla terminó así.
Como tenemos el rol de un Ingeniero, entonces hay que saber resolver los puzzles con ingenio, no es nada al azar, y al resolver esos puzzles, uno se siente con una satisfacción enorme.
Incluso he tenido ganas de realizar exploración urbana, solo para vivir lo que hacemos con nuestro personaje, gracias a este juego (no recomendado para idiotas).

Recomiendo este juego para todo amante de la Ingeniería, el paisajismo, la música Ambient y los puzzles. 10/10.

21804098.review:
INFRA é um jogo puzzle independente no qual você investigará uma série de acontecimentos em uma pequena cidade envolvendo uma grande corporação e sua atuação recente. 

A ambientação do jogo é maravilhosa, com ótima arte e lindas paisagens. Obviamente, em tons de pouca saturação, para adicionar tensão à atmosfera em que te coloca. O mais interessante do universo, além do tamanho, é como ele é interativo. Você não tem dicas do que fazer, o que torna o jogo uma verdadeira aventura de exploração.

Você terá em mãos apenas sua câmera e uma lanterna, e você deverá fotografar as pistas que te levarão, mais à frente, a desvendar o caso.

Aliás, é incrível como os puzzles são construídos. Você coleta elementos enquanto avança, e cabe a você ler os documentos, interpretar os sinais e compreender o que deve ser feito em seguida. Neste sentido, inclusive lembra o recente jogo aclamado pela crítica, The Witness. 

O máximo que o jogo faz, é destacar os objetos com os quais você pode interagir. Mas esse é o máximo. Ele não te diz o que é uma dica para o próximo passo, ou uma dica para resolver o mistério, como você deve interpretar, com mais informações aquela dica deve ser complementada. É tudo com você! O jogo não te subestima!

Além de puzzles baseados apenas em texto, possui também uma boa variedade em puzzles que combinam texto com lógica (como, por exemplo, fazer um equipamento funcionar).

O áudio é bom. Principalmente, porque não é intrusivo e não se destaca. Apenas sons ambientes. Seja da natureza quando se está no aberto, ou de maquinaria quando se está dentro dos prédios. Ele possui boas músicas épicas, mas apenas em seus ápices, o que é sensacional para criar a atmosfera de suspense. Como disse, o som, música, tudo é muito bem dosado.

O que mais se destacou da arte na minha opinião foi a iluminação. Mesmo não possuindo as texturas de mais alta resolução (o que não significa ter baixa resolução), o som é tem uma iluminação tão boa que dá personalidade à direção de arte. E quando digo iluminação é tudo, deste a fotografia aos efeitos que luzes criam (glow, etc). É um jogo bem bonito.

A história do jogo pode ser um pouco clichê (você contra grandes corporações), mas funciona. É adulta o suficiente, é contada de forma interessante através das notas e te mantém interessado em saber o que vai acontecer. E o seu jogo será totalmente diferente do jogo do seu amigo, pois você tem muitas opções para atingir diversos objetivos.  Por ser uma espécie de open-world sandbox, nem todo problema só possui uma forma de ser resolvido. Você pode interagir de diversas formas com o universo na busca de uma solução. Algumas partes só serão acessíveis de uma forma, mas ainda assim.

Já os puzzles são muito bons. Não são tão complexos como de outros jogos focados só nisso (lembremos que INFRA tem aspectos de suspense também, não chega a ser terror, mas ele tem outros elementos), mas são bem pensados e você passará um bom tempo tentando resolver alguns deles.

O jogo tem alguns bugs, mas nada demais. 

Pros:

- Som, trilha sonora. Não intrusivos e usados inteligentemente.
- Bons gráficos, com personalidade e boa iluminação.
- Ótimos puzzles, bem inteligentes e desafiantes.
- Muito explorável muito interessante e interativo.

Contra:

- Poucos bugs.
- A história é boa, mas o "story-telling" não é perfeito. Poderia ser melhor. Mas eu entendo que seja como é em um jogo mais aberto e menos linear.

21769950.review:
[h1]Basic Information[/h1]
[b]Title: INFRA
Genre: Adventure, Indie
Developer: Loiste Interactive 
Publisher: Loiste Interactive	
Release Date: 15 Jan, 2016[/b]

[h1]Basic Overview[/h1]
Infra is a very atmospheric, first-person adventure game, with some puzzles and some platforming. The puzzles themselves have a wide range, from the most simplistic, to rather challenging. The game itself looks great, the graphics and shaders really seemed to take effect to the game itself. There seems to have been a lot of work on everything on this game, from the stunning graphics and scenery to the puzzles.

[h1]Game Play[/h1]
This game focuses mostly on puzzles, and have some puzzle-platforming parts of the game as well. It makes a nice change to the game rather than sticking to just puzzles all the time. Some of the puzzles that you may encounter in this game are either simplistic or rather difficult. The challenge of the game increases as you proceed through the game, the puzzles get harder and therefore require you to think more about how to solve them. The game starts at a slow pace in the way of solving puzzles, and the ouzzles seem to be one right after the other. The game itself isn't completely open world, but there is a decent amount of areas to explore if you are the kind of person who likes exploring places that aren't always 100% necessary to do so. A point that I didn't like about the rather difficult puzzles where the situations where you would just die over and over again until you can figure out what to do. This got me rather fustrated and made me stop playing for a small remainder of time. Thankfully this game has autosave checkpoints which slightly lowered my furstration when dying over and over but still pushed me enough to make me stop playing for a little bit. The story line of the game is really good, it's very interesting and made me come back to play more if I ever did break out of fustration at times of the game.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The graphics of this game are absolutely stunning. I can't even begin to imagine how much work the developers must've put into this to make it look as good as it does. Although most of the game will be going into dark and gloomy places, there still seems to be a lot of work been put into this game. When you are platforming on the game, it gives you a chance to see more of the contryside that you couldn't normally see.

[h1]Music & Sound[/h1]
The game really does well when it comes to the sounds when you are in the different locations of the game, depending if you are outside or inside a dark gloomy area, it really helps set the atmosphere up for the game. The sounds of the birds whistling when you are outdoors really makes it feel like a peaceful place to be in, along with the soundtrack which gives off a really nice ambient type of music (Deluxe edition).

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Infra is a very atmospheric and fun game to play. With it's vast amount of puzzles varied difficulty on some of the parts of the game, along with all of the sounds that you hear outside and in other places that set the atmosphere of thw game all togehter. Would recommend those of you who like puzzle games to definatly buy this!

21702160.review:
INFRA:
~~~~~  
 
The National Consulting Group is a structural surveyor company and won a contract with Stalburg City. As you are one of the most talented surveyors within the company, you have been called to a very important early meeting. The gig is very simple; you are assigned to a specific area to check on all the buildings that were not maintained properly by your predecessor. 

INFRA is a first person/adventure/puzzle game where you play Mark, a structural surveyor who has to check on buildings in a specific area of the Stalburg City region. You will be armed with a flashlight and a camera. As you go alone in your journey, you will spot damage on buildings and record it by taking shots with your camera. You will encounter dark, enclosed areas and will use more than once your flashlight to navigate or to find additional batteries for your camera and flashlight. In your journey, you will gather information about your location by reading posts and letters, which, by the way, can sometimes give you valuable hints.

You will encounter interesting puzzles to solve in this game; they are not that complex but might take you some time to get it right. Just make sure you read every post and letter. 
I must admit I was taken by surprise with the stunning graphics and scenery in this game - just brilliant, to be honest! The voice acting is just ok in my opinion.

I had some loading and crash issues here and there, but nothing too drastic.

Positives:
~~~~~~~ 

-	Stunning graphics and scenery
-	Good story-line
-	Interesting puzzles
-	Achievements

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	A couple of crashes here and there.

INFRA is an interesting game with stunning graphics!

8/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

21688988.review:
[b]INFRA[/b] is a puzzle walking simulator that starts you out investigating problems with a dam that is falling apart in a small town of Stalburg and uncover a conspiracy behind the events leading up to the mismanagement and downfall of these important areas of the town.  You use your camera to find disturbances and clues as to what is happening, as well as taking pictures of any documentation and other evidence that could "aid the cause" of the company you're working with.

I will go through my rundown of what I thought was good and bad, and give a few more tidbits of why I like this game overall, and how I came to giving this one a "thumbs up".


[h1]Pros:[/h1]

Nice environments and scenery.  Easy to learn the controls, as with many walking sims.  

I like the camera in the game.  It's cool seeing the picture in picture, and taking pictures of things that should be repaired, or were neglected.  

I enjoy the idea of having to be very observant in order to find things that are not quite right.  It is 
nice since I don't like rushing through games, and promotes slowing down and examining your surroundings.

I like finding the pieces to the broken elements or fixing things along the way.  

Expansive game, with a lot more to it than I first thought.  Trying to figure out the puzzles took me a 
while to complete many sections of the game.

I like the various traps to overcome, and the changing environment as you get deeper into the game. 

 
[h1]Cons:[/h1]

I don't much care for the voice acting, especially when I first started out.  It took some getting used to for me to adjust to it.  I don't really feel much connection with the protagonist either, so that is a little bit dry for me.  I would have liked to have a little more dialog, but at the same time I guess it is in the character's personality to be very matter-of-fact and not the talkative sort.  

I did not know you could throw objects you pick up until a good bit later, so I would have liked seeing this in the initial part of the tutorial phase.

The backtracking and trying to figure out what to do to go onwards can get a little bit frustrating.  It's 
easy to miss something, only to have to backtrack quite a bit in order to move forward in progression.

I can't really tell where each save has me at, if I am curious.  I would really like an area select, so I could work on particular areas again if I wanted to go back.  I'm not sure if there is a way other than the four save slots.

Loading screens are a bit lengthy and break up the continuity and fluidity of the gameplay.  They can take a bit of time.


[h1]Glitches:[/h1]  

Heard the train horn go off after the train was stopped on the other side of the bridge.  Also I turned around at the train tracks for a second, then when I turned back the train was already at its destination.

Sometimes on reloads, certain sound effects would cut out for me.  

I had a few times where I got killed in strange ways.  A box near a ledge might turn, and I'd suddenly die.  If I was not careful on my exploration, I might get trapped beside rocks, or other obstacles. 

I also trapped myself by doing stupid stuff with items I was able to carry, so use caution when moving these types of things around.  I had to reload a checkpoint or two because of my carefree attitude with things I could grab in the game.

Not so much a glitch, but the controller for me was a little bit clunky, when compared to the mouse.  For example, if I was trying to select something on a computer screen map, I couldn't be nearly as precise as with a mouse.  The same thing if i were interacting with something by looking at it.  Hard to determine where I needed to focus with the controller at times, but zooming in could help a bit sometimes.  I liked having the ability to move between one or the other though.


[h1]Other Thoughts:[/h1]

Save often, as you can get stuck in places, or die, and it will become your checkpoint.  Collecting the items is a nice bonus as well for achievements, if you're into that sort of thing.  They are not so easy to find though, in many cases.  While not gigantic, the game is fairly expansive and immense for something of a walking sim/puzzle.  From my experience, others I have played were much shorter.  

After finishing one playthrough, I would have to play through again to get the achievements I have missed.  I would have liked to have some kind of level select to try to complete more of my achievements too, but I could not find anything like this.  I believe that would improve the desire to replay the game.  I would love to have some sort of map feature, so I could tell where I am at certain times.  It can get a bit confusing while moving from place to place, and I think this would have enhanced my experience just a bit.  As for resources, I didn't really ever come close to running out of batteries for flashlight or camera, and with proper exploration, they are very plentiful.  I also used both fairly sparingly whenever possible.  

Overall, I really enjoyed this game, and I am glad I played it!  I would recommend to people who are into a more laid back and somewhat relaxing cinematic-style experience.  I could see most people enjoying this game though.  It was a breath of fresh air for me to see the combination of elements put together in the game.  It worked well, I thought.  For me, this fell more in line with that cinematic style, but there are moments where you have to act fast to survive.  I liked the dynamic changing world around you too.  The colors and textures were pleasing to the eye, and I wanted to keep playing, which is a great thing.  I wish there were a little more story involved during your own personal struggle to get through though.  With the place falling apart around you, there were many times you just could not go back, and while I expected bad things to happen, it was still surprising in the well done placement of many of the various dangers.  Great game overall!

[b]** Disclaimer:  I was given a key to review the game.  This had no impact on my rating**[/b]

21657100.review:
[h1] INFRA [/h1]

INFRA is a game which I personally found very enjoyable. The gameplay consists of a large variety of fairly accurate electrical and mechanical puzzles. I found the pacing to be perfectly blended with fast paced moments evenly spread across the game.

 The visuals serve as a testimony of what an old engine such as Source can still achieve. The developers have clearly stretched the engine to its maximum capabilities to create this game.

The soundtrack is brilliantly composed and consists of a mix of industrial, ambient and action-oriented tracks which I find myself listening to outside of the game.

However, the main thing which I find carries this game, is the message behind it.  INFRA tells a very real story about a city which isn’t too different from yours or mine and shows events which can likely happen if we refuse to take care of our infrastructure.

Although the game is not without its flaws. There are a handful of visual and gameplay glitches scattered throughout the games. Fortunately, the developers have been very active in fixing issues within the game and helping out the player base.

INFRA is a game I find enjoyable but it might not be for everyone. The game has a slower pace, is currently unfished and mainly consist of documenting, walking and solving puzzles. Something I could see not appeal to me if I had more action orientated tastes.

[b]Disclaimer: [/b]
I obtained a free INFRA key for beta testing purposes in the last wave before the games release (2016), however I was already intending to purchase INFRA before this.

21617543.review:
[h1]Infra is an Indie atmospheric mystery adventure that doubles as a physics puzzler by day, with minimal and realistic platforming.[/h1]
It is a must have for anyone who likes mysteries and crime dramas. I love the genre myself, so was delighted to find something new. With the narrative of Stanley’s Parable, and the stimulating puzzles of Portal, Infra is sure to be worth the price. 

[b]Physics in Motion:[/b]
Things move, and you move with them. The world is more than just a traditional set of “maps.” Each map location contains physically responsive pieces of machinery. These provide open-ended exploration opportunities for the gamer to solve puzzles that were not spoon-fed to him. This one will not insult your intelligence with big arrows on screen shouting, “click here.” Either you find them or you don’t and you keep moving. Nobody’s holding your hand here. And there is none of that, “pile everything up and see what you can craft” mechanics either. 

[b]Graphics:[/b]
The artwork is well done and often panoramic in outdoor scenes. The platforming gives you great chances to see more of the view around the countryside. The graphics are satisfying in a nostalgic way. For a game that makes such low demands on the hardware, the graphics come out mid-range. The locations are mostly dark and dingy so, it is a whole different type of atmosphere, as in Late Garage-Sale/Early Thrift Shop antique furniture. Hitting things causes dust to rise.

[b]Sound:[/b]
It’s easy to get immersed in the sound effects of birds and nature when in the outdoor areas. Ambient effects like birds whistling give it an airy and peaceful feel. I have the deluxe edition with a soundtrack of the ambient music. 

[b]Lighting Matters:[/b]
Colors on puzzles often play optical tricks in less than true color if you don’t check them with the flashlight. Ignore this at your own risk. 
Batteries, though plentiful, have to be located and collected as you go. Only turn on the flashlight to see then cut it right back off, moving without it when you can or you’ll be whining in the dark later. 

[b]Telling Story:[/b]
Infra is a story of corporate disillusionment, where corruption has left a man’s dreams as a rotting nightmare. I haven’t finished the game yet, so I have no idea where this is headed. But, I feel like I have walked into the middle of a conspiracy. The story is definitely intriguing and draws you in to complete the missions.

[b]Photographer:[/b]
You are chronicling the story as you go, but the mechanics of the camera are highly restrictive in what is considered “correct” evidence of structural damage. Limitations of batteries will force you to think and evaluate machinery, rather than just randomly snapping photos, hoping for something to come out right.
The game presents puzzles and keys to proceed through doors, and therefore the story is quite linear. However, the detective work consists in sleuthing out all the hidden codes and evidence alongside the linear route. This lends replay-ability to the game, since you will need more than the first run through to locate all the things you missed. 
I found it important to take screenshots of codes, numbers, and puzzles for further analysis after the first run through, as I have not memorized binary code, and I am not experienced with code-breaking. There are undoubtedly numerous types of codes located throughout for you code-breaking junkies out there. 
The locations in the story are extremely dilapidated and hazardous to your health. In the first chapters, I thought I would die traversing the electrified water spots. But, I made it through those just fine and broke my neck trying to jump off a roof onto a window ledge. It makes it all the more realistic, because accidents happen when you get too comfortable in a hazardous environment.

[b]Choices:[/b]
As you play you will find chances to repair things yourself. Your decisions affect the outcome of your play-through. Everything matters. The map is highly accessable, with multiple routes for many of the missions. 

[b]Pros: [/b]
Not cartoony, and decidedly adult in content/ Not another Nancy Drew or Sherlock Holmes Mystery
Technologically and Environmentally relevant plot 
User-friendly game-play mechanics, real life tools
Voice acting is enjoyable. 
Real adventure gaming at it’s best. 
Mentally challenging / Intelligent puzzles

[b]Cons: [/b]
Not an adrenaline ride thus far, just serious crime sleuthing in hazardous environments.
No guns… you’re shooting pictures here. 
No inventory to collect, except those batteries 
Not a point & click Mystery, & no Hidden Object puzzles, I’m sorry. 

[b]I highly recommend Infra to gamers in every genre, as it has something for everyone.[/b]
Time in game is sure to vary depending on your code-breaking experience. A simple speed run through could be done in just 3 hours by experienced gamers, where I have 5 hours already and just into the 3rd chapter.  Achievements are nicely aligned to provide something extra for fastidious types who like to find all the details and enjoy the atmosphere. I will certainly be watching Loiste Interactive for more great games. Meanwhile, I have some more clues to find in Infra… and this is just the first episode.

21603674.review:
Infra is a 'puzzleventure' game with loads of exploration, puzzles and avoiding hazardous environments. The most impressive about the game is definitely the intense atmosphere created by detailed industrial installations and beautiful surroundings.

You play as Mark, a cynical structural analyst who's task is to document the state of the infrastructue of Stalburg city. What sounds like a boring every-day mission turns out to be a real trip: In the aftermath of a corruption scandal the whole infrastructure of Stalburg is abandoned and left to rot. You try your best to document damage with your camera, repair generators and electrical installations and generally not to die in the hazardous environments left in the once busy industrial complexes. On your way, you may even uncover the complot behind all of this.
There are many optional tasks in Infra, e.g repairing installations, getting the water supply & putrification back in shape and many more, so even a 2nd playthrough may be worth your while.

Infra constantly gets updated, and the developers are very busy developing chapter 2 of the story which will be free for everyone current owner.

21509636.review: Geweldig spel. Het feit dat je geen idee hebt waar je naar zoekt of waar je eigenlijk mee bezig bent, maakt het verbazingwekkend interessant. Ik vind de beelden mooi, sfeer en stijl. Ik hou ervan. Sommige dingen zijn een beetje irritant. Soms duur het even voordat je precies weet wat je moet doen, maar als je eenmaal weet wat je moet doen en het lukt je een uur lang niet om net precies ergens op te springen... veel saven haha, scheelt een eind teruglopen iedere keer.

21496719.review:
The game is visually nice and a lot of work has clearly gone in to it. The levels are big and there is a lot to explore. Yet the game feels unfinished. Most of the time you don't know what you are doing and where you are going, which could be ok if you would get rewarded (which you don't) for wandering around and checking every corner like in other exploration games.

The voice acting was horrible, especially on the part of the main character. With the given voice of our hero, the letter a in the flashlight sounds more like an e, which then again might be humorous... The game was doing it's best to be funny, but managed to do this in quite a childish way. Most non-Finnish people won't probably find the ever-present beer references amusing.

The game has some climbing and jumping elements, for which the character movement isn't very well suited. Especially the part requiring jumping or other athletics were frustrating as our hero can't really do these things. When this was couple insta-death situations (dropping to water etc.) or running against time situations, it wasn't really enjoyable. Is this poor map design, a challenge or did I miss some important controls when I would always end up in the river when taking what seemed to be a short cut?

As for the puzzles and the story, well, I lost interest in them. The puzzles became something I had to do in order to open a door to continue and I couldn't get any joy out of that after a while. Something was missing to keep me interested and motivated, something didn't make the world believable. Still, I managed to complete the game, though I could have just as easily given up after losing interest.

While investigating the problems of the infrastructure and corruption behind it seemed like a nice idea, it felt like a bad hobby (because of not getting anything in return, just to advance to next location). There was no benefit in doing it. Also there is some illogical aspect in this, a hole in the bridge or a wall should be reported but blocked fire escapes and other clear structural defect and dangerous things shouldn't be? I really couldn't understand sometimes what I was supposed to document and what not.

So, who should buy this game? If you like exploring and solving puzzles, maybe this is your game. The idea had novelty value, but somehow the end result didn't feel like a ready game. So maybe instead of part 2, this part 1 should be finished?

21494024.review:

21490310.review:
Flawed, but I still really like it. Lots of enjoyable playtime. Had only a few moments of frustration. The voice acting is subpar, but I heard it's getting a rework. Also, according to an achivement there are 100 geocaches hidden in Infra but I've only found 4. (edit: There are not 100 caches. There are 16.) Also, I need part 2.

edit: Wow, this game seems polarizing. Here's my opinion on it: Do take your time while playing a game? If yes, you'll like Infra. If you like to play faster, then you probably won't.

edit2: Part two is out! And it's really, really, cool. Goes in a spookier direction, no jumpscares but the atmosphere is amazing. There seem to be huge eastereggs in the game about the plot- some things in part 2 are just crazy, in a good way. Some details are just incredible in this game. However, I do have some problems. Some puzzles are kind of weak, but overall they're fine. And chances are that if you're playing part two you don't really care about Mark's voice acting. And overall part 2 is pretty amazing

edit3: Part 3 came out! And It's pretty rad- the puzzles were good (but the drainage pool one seems like it would be nearly impossible to nail the first time), the levels were amazing, the story still pretty obfuscated- I got to admit, I have no idea what's going on with the story- and the atmosphere great. As usual, you need a pretty attentive eye (something i sometimes lack) to proceed. I really enjoyed this game as a whole- while I do have problems as stated above, I stil think this is a great game. So y'know, buy it and finish it. The ending was pretty satisfying w/ after credits scene, very glad it was there.

21190000.review:
When I purchased INFRA I was looking for a slower paced game with some puzzle solving and some interesting world exploration.  INFA delivered on all fronts.  My first play through took about 15 hrs (currently at 65 hrs and have played through the game at least 4 times looking for achievements).  I'm looking forward to episode 2 (which will be free for those who purchase episode 1).  I have really enjoyed my time with this game.

I would describe INFRA as an environmental puzzle game with a decades old conspiracy story at its heart.  You play a structural engineer working for a private firm which has just been awarded a contract to manage infrastructure maintenance for Stalburg, a fictional European city.  You are sent to survey bridges, a dam, a power plant, etc. and document (i.e. photograph) any need for repairs.  Along the way you uncover documents about an old conspiracy which led to the city's current state disrepair.

The game starts off somewhat slow in terms of puzzle solving and ends with nearly one puzzle right after another.  There is plenty to do.  The game is not open world but offers a decent amount of urban exploration of decaying infrastructure along with some beautiful views.  There's also a pervasive undercurrent of dry humor which I really enjoyed.

Puzzle difficulty ranges from almost too simple to extremely difficult.  Most deal with manipulating machinery of some kind, although there are some platforming puzzles too.  There are some crisis situations where you just die, die, and die again until you figure things out.  Not my favorite type of puzzle, but fortunately autosave checkpoints are really well done to minimize frustration.  (You can also save anywhere.)  Coded messages are also hidden in the game.  Some in binary, others encrypted.  I'm not really into that sort of thing, but I appreciate it being there for those that are.

My biggest gripe with the game is actually just moving around.  I'm forever getting caught up on doorways, ladders, railings, low ceilings.  Maybe that's just a product of the Source engine, maybe it's just me.  There's also a battery requirement for the flashlight and camera.  Batteries run out quite fast in this game.  There are plenty of batteries to be found though, no need to be miserly with either.  Perhaps the batteries were a game mechanic meant to encourage exploration.  Regardless, it can get exapserating with how frequently you need to replace them.

INFRA is a bit rough around the edges.  Some parts of the game are beautiful and some parts look unfinished or unpolished.  The voice acting ranges from fine to bad.  The underlying logic of why you need to solve X to accomplish Y is sometimes missing, or mystifying.  The puzzles themselves were not hard to recognize and there are usually notes or hints to guide you to solutions.

I recommend this game if you are into puzzle games like Portal, the Vanishing of Ethan Carter, and The Talos Principle.  INFRA is roughly in the same vein.  INFRA's pros outweigh its cons and absolutely delivers on urban exploration and puzzle solving.

21041299.review:
INFRA is the story of a structural analyst who seems to enjoy ending up in life threatening situations, and has scant regard for his own personal safety, working for a consulting firm who clearly sees hard hats as the pinnacle of heath and safety, happy send their staff alone into potentially unsafe bits of infrastructure.

OK, snark mode off, INFRA is a very impressive game for the price. It has it's flaws, and it can be frustrating at times for all the wrong reasons, but the effort put in to the locations and enviroments shines through. The one thing that stood out for me the most was the realism I got from the sheer attention to detail. The devs have clearly done their location research, starting all the way with the office at the beginning, through to every piece of infrastructure in the game. Occasionally some breaks from reality are present for gameplay reasons (our protagonists rather liberal interpretation of health and safety protocols included, [spoiler]as well as the general lack of safety features within the infrastructure, though the story may give some reasons for this[/spoiler]), but from the offices to the shop floor, there was a definite sense of immersion that came with such realistic detail.

My main critcisms would be that it relies a little too much on "first person platforming", much like half-life did back in the day, the puzzles often rely on obscurity rather than logic (though this may have been a good thing, real infrastructre doesn't want to make you solve the soup cans before shutting down a malfunctioning turbine!), and sometimes it's not obvious what your immediate objective is, particularly as there are often multiple paths which can leave you worried you've missed something.

Overall, a great game for the price, and worth it for an enjoyable weekend play.

20946548.review:
En INFRA nos ponemos en la piel de Mark, un analista estructural cuyo día de trabajo rutinario empieza a complicarse de una manera que nunca podría haber imaginado. Equipados con nuestra cámara de fotos y fiel linterna, en un principio deberemos inspeccionar determinadas instalaciones y conseguir documentos gráficos de los desperfectos que ponen en peligro a la ciudad de Stalburg.

Este no es el típico juego del género al que uno puede estar acostumbrado, ya que no hay que acabar con enemigos ni destruir otros elementos. Se trata de un título en primera persona en el que deberemos resolver determinados puzles relacionados con el mantenimiento de instalaciones, tanto para avanzar en los escenarios como para encontrar más detalles sobre la historia. El desarrollo puede parecer un tanto lento y pausado, es por ello que puede no ser plato de buen gusto para todo el mundo. Sin embargo si tienes un mínimo de interés es bastante probable que seas recompensado por ello. No hay que confundir con títulos como Dear Esther u otros similares cuyo enfoque es distinto, pese a que en un primer vistazo pudiera parecer que son similares, en lo único que se parecen es en alejarse de los cánones establecidos sobre los videojuegos en primera persona. Aunque en realidad sí tenemos enemigos, y son las construcciones del hombre dándose la mano con la fragilidad de la integridad estructural, con todo lo que ello conlleva.

Pese a que por motivos obvios no es una aventura donde predomine la acción, sí que hay varios momentos donde la tensión nos obligará a ser rápidos e intentar evitar situaciones de verdadero peligro. Acostumbrarse demasiado al ritmo predominante de este título puede suponer un grave error cuando las cosas cambian.

Algo a tener sin duda muy en cuenta es la parte visual de los escenarios, con toda una serie de detalles, contraste de colores, luces y sombras que amenizan aún más si cabe nuestro avance. Uno nunca pensaría que un título de una temática como esta pudiera conseguir ofrecer una visión artística tan notable, y esto último es algo que se puede apreciar a simple vista en varias de las capturas que tiene. No obstante el diseño de los personajes (visualmente hablando) no me gustó demasiado.

En lo que se refiere a la historia se nos presenta de determinadas formas, aunque todas ellas en su justa medida. Aparte de las conversaciones con nuestros compañeros disfrutaremos de comentarios en solitario de nuestro personaje, notas y señales (narrativa visual), e incluso textos, diarios, informes y grabaciones que nos ayudarán a destapar toda una trama detrás de los acontecimientos y a darle mayor sentido a lo que nos rodea.

La banda sonora es bastante correcta, y encaja con los lugares y situaciones que se nos presentan.

Personalmente y aunque en los primeros compases el juego me dejó un poco frío, tal cual fui avanzando todo empezó a volverse mucho más interesante porque los aspectos que ya he mencionado empezaron a brillar con luz propia.

Actualmente solo se dispone de la primera parte, que ofrece en torno a las 10-12 horas de juego (en mi caso incluso unas pocas más), no obstante la parte restante y una vez finalizada estará incluida para todos los que ya hubieran adquirido el juego anteriormente.

Está completamente traducido al español por un servidor, aunque de momento de manera no oficial (se puede encontrar la traducción en la sección de guías).

20714931.review:
A thoroughly enjoyable, beautiful exploration game with plenty of great ideas only lacking in polish and general quality assurance. Some of the puzzles throughout the game are brilliant, but others are really not that good (I'm looking at you, raft section and all the elecrified floor jumpathons). I like the scandinavian aesthetic as I am a Finn myself (really brought me back to my heydays in Kontula with the above ground segments) and I really loved the nature segments as well.

Above all, the game really needs some solid hints. I got through most of the game without a hitch, but some solutions are not so obvious and could use for example the player's voice to guide through them. I think there should be a prelude "routine infrastructure case" before coming to the office, a small tutorial course where you need to photograph, flashlight and get used to the mazelike urbex gameplay of INFRA. The game could really use one where you learn some not-so-obvious things like stacking crates and such. I really loved the office, but only in hindsight as it's a bit too good at showcasing the gameplay elements...it's just too much too fast and might scare more casual players away.

I gotta hand it to you Oskutin & friends, the level design is phenomenal. There are some really amazing vistas and you managed to squeeze everything out of Source. I loved the blast furnace tower. I really really loved the little landscapes near the dam and the little suburban canal section. Top marks on the hacker den too - that place was fun as hell to go through. The waterfalls, the dam, everything is so peaceful, serene yet manage to get the atmospheric 'spooky' factor to the max. 

The unpolishness is making this a bit of a tough sell. There's a LOT of spelling errors, confusing sentences and overall weirdness going about. In my playthrough, none of the audiologs worked so I didn't get much out of the storyline. I'll play it through again when part 2 is out (lovely cliffhanger by the way). You really need someone to fix those quirks in text and script when you get around finishing the entire experience.

There are also quite a few bugs. Physics glitches, sound issues and such were thankfully quite fast patched, but there are some lingering issues that almost all pertain to the engine itself. There's a crane that can detach its load in late chapter 5 that can kill your playthrough unless you reload a checkpoint, if you do things in wrong order with a certain forklift. There's some inconsistencies in level design where that cool area you found might not go anywhere at all. There's the infuriating pixel-perfect-or-you're-dead raft section that makes me want to skewer the one who okay'd that through QA. I hope these gets fixed after part 2 is out, since these really destroy the immersion and experience.

And boy, what an experience it is. I'm almost inclined to go romping around abandoned factories and facilities in real life after having so much fun exploring these urban ruins. The camera mechanic is genius, if only you'd give more batteries to play around with. The puzzles are creative and the nice crisis scenes you get from time to time are well thought out and executed. A phenomenal title focused solely on urbex and puzzling, beautifully laid out in an urban yet natural scandinavian wonderland. Few more spit shine polish elements and I'd give this a solid 10/10, but I'll have to go with 8/10, with one point out for repeated 'electrified water' and 'stack the boxes' gags and the second one for unpolishness and the infuriating raft section. Did I mention how I hated that part yet? Seriously, it is beyond terrible.

Overall, 8/10, would heavily recommend. Hyvää työtä Suomen pojat! :D

20709968.review:
INFRA is interesting. I went in thinking it'd be like Myst in terms of puzzles, and I was right for the most part. I also spent a lot of the game wondering where my character's accent was from. Overall, I enjoyed the game. It had a very high attention to detail and the world was a believable one. Several puzzles were real thinkers, where it'd take me quite a while of running around trying doors and switches until it came together. My complaints of the game are that about half of the time I was playing, I was wondering, "What the hell do I do now?" Backtracking wasn't a huge issue, but in some of the more open levels I'd throw a switch and then run around trying to find out what changed. I also noticed several spelling and grammatical errors in letters and newspapers, which are often difficult to read because it's so small. 
Overall, I'd give it a thumbs up. It's worth a try.

20676396.review:
This is not a bad game, it's rather nice, but it is unfinished.

I hope I will rewrite this review when the game gets patched a few more times, and hope to change my recommendation to thumbs up. Currently the game is a drag, and that's a shame, because I really want to like this game. It has a unique atmosphere and does (tries to do) something different from most games today. I wouldn't have bothered to write this review if I didn't like this game, but in it's current state I cannot recommend it.

My main issue is that it feels very much like an alpha release, and definitely should still be in Early Access. But as that is not the case, I fear some of the weird design features will not be rectified. I will list a few issues I have with the game below.

The game world is not logical. It appears to be, but is far from it. Abandoned places still have electric lights on, and every place is generally too well lit; makes me wonder why do I even have a torch with me. People have left notes lying around which are obviously there to help me, but would make no sense in a real world. Usually these notes are right next to the puzzle and basically tell you how to solve it, so it's not really a puzzle but "follow instructions" type of a problem. I got stuck at the sawmill for several hours because I didn't notice an attic window, which for some unnatural reason had a plank protruding from it, and I was supposed to go through there. Never in my life I've seen something like that in real life, so I didn't think to look for it. It makes sense in game, kinda, but I've never liked puzzles which do not rely on real world logic but impose their own on the player. There are other kind of logical problems which break the immersion, like finding a dead body but not reporting it to anyone immediately, and halting a train but not communicating to the crew in any way, etc.

There are several places in the game world where you can get stuck, like falling between some rocks. Otherwise the character can climb low obstacles, but apparently 50 cm of rock is too much for him. This wouldn't be a problem, as most of these places are off the beaten path, but the game suggests that it rewards exploration. And I like that, it's nice that there are places you can walk around, which are there just for the atmosphere, but as it is, it's way too easy to get stuck or fall into water (instadeath, naturally). This is all made worse by the save game system, which doesn't tell you which save slot you used last (nor name the saves), and doesn't ask if you want to overwrite your last save. Additionally you can also get to areas from which you cannot go back, so saves are somewhat important, yeah.

The voice acting is pretty bad, but okay I guess for an indie developers budjet. The English used in the notes found in game is rather awful, with a lot of typos and poor grammar. Almost every note found has some mistakes in it. Another thing related to this is the weird nation the game takes place in, as it seems to be some sort of strange hybrid of Finland, USA, UK and some East European countries. The main character speaks like he's Slavish, but still speaks in (very broken) English, and most of the names are English as well, yet there are some Finnish products and words here and there. Pontikka is moonshine in English, so why would the characters in game use the Finnish word? This would've worked so much better if the whole game was set in Finland, or if the protagonist or another major character was Finnish living in whatever country this is supposed to be set in. Being a Finn myself, I'd love to see a pretty game like this set in Finland.

The main character's camera uses AA batteries and runs out of them after a couple of shots, doesn't zoom or record video, and you cannot look at what pictures you have taken. I guess the state of decay extends to the city officials equipment as well. The protagonist should know his camera is a POS, and pack extra batteries, but no, he prefers to rely on luck, finding fresh batteries in buildings abandoned for years or decades. Feels like a producer told the dev team that if there aren't any guns, there still should be reloading and ammo pickups. Please. Hunting for batteries adds nothing to the game and is just plain irritating. The fact that you can't look at the pictures you've taken is also a missed opportunity, as taking a picture of a found schematic and checking it from the camera later when you actually have to solve a puzzle would make much more immersive gameplay than finding the instructions right next to every puzzle.

The good? As I stated above, the game is unique in atmosphere. Mix of slow paced exploration and puzzle solving is a great idea, and at times works very well. The game looks good enough, but runs very unevenly, freezing sometimes for no reason for a second or two, and having other graphical glitches like doorways that are nothing but bright white light until you walk through them. The sounds are good and the sparsely used music fits the game well. The environments are somewhat unusual for games, as there are areas which seem to offer nothing but places to walk around. I like that, makes the world feel all the more real. Many of the puzzles are fun enough and most of the locations look like they could actually exist. This is by no definition a bad game, but it could be so much better than it currently is.

I haven't finished the game yet, so maybe there are more things I'll like later in the game, I don't know. Had to stop playing because it got so annoying to deal with everything above that I had to write this review. Currently I can only enjoy this game if I play it 15-20 minutes at a time, any longer and I want to rip my eyes out, out of pure frustration. This has the potential to be an amazing game, and I won't give up on it. Score : 5½ / 10.

20676095.review:
Loiste Interactive: INFRA is the Steam debut for Loiste Interactive a small gaming development and self-publishing firm located in Finland. The game had humble beginnings as a Source Engine mod project  that eventually grew large enough to become its own fully fledged title.  The game drew a rabid fan base whilst it was in the Steam Greenlight program attracting more than 45,000 votes and peaking at #4 on the Greenlight Charts. It wasn’t until the developers understood just how popular their title was that they ultimately decided to create the company from that – until this point it was a group of friends who were working on their mod together. Soon thereafter thanks to some investment into the company the group were able to commit themselves to their project on a permanent full time basis.

Pre-Steam Release Acclaim: To show just how popular INFRA had become the game received a number of nominations and awards during its development cycle beginning in 2011 with selection to the top one hundred “Mod of the Year” list by ModDB, earning Greenlit status the following year on Steam and peaking with a nod from IndieDB as a top one hundred selection to “2014 Indie of the Year Awards.”

A grand beginning: The first episode in the INFRA episodic adventure, part two will be free for purchasers of the first part, averages about ten hours in play. You play the role of a structural analyst whose tasked with the job of navigating, and hopefully surviving, a brutal labyrinth. As it says in the Steam Description, it is a gun-free puzzle adventure. Intelligence and strategy are awarded as you work your way through some of the most rewarding interactive puzzles to be seen in gaming in recent times. It’s an ambitious opening act that offers highly rewarding gameplay.

Large maps that truly inspire you to explore: Almost from the very beginning you will be surprised at just how large the maps in the game are. Although I found the office section to be more than a little tedious  – it’s main purpose  is to serve as a tutorial – I was surprised at just how large the area was. This continues right throughout the episode. They are all highly detailed featuring a number of different potential routes and offered a feeling of an open world better than some true open world games. Each area is filled with puzzles and unique game play that really does make you feel that you’re not repeating the same things over and over again. The game design has been very well thought out. The maps provide you ample opportunities to explore and to try different ideas with all of this feeling very rewarding. I quite enjoyed the distinct looks and sounds of the various areas. The environments are lush and beautiful. It genuinely feels as though Loiste Interactive thought of everything to create an immersive experience for the players.

It’s not perfect: There are a number of flaws in the game. However, I believe that this can be explained by the availability of resources for development and the relative inexperience of the development team. Overall, I believe that these flaws can be overlooked but they are notable. First, I was worried that I couldn’t even start the game. I don’t necessarily put games straight onto my SSD. Consequently, I put INFRA onto my HDD and it stayed there. When I first loaded up the game I got long periods of black screens to the point where I quit the game multiple times believing that the game had crashed on me. I believe on the third or fourth attempt I just said to hell with it and got myself a drink. I soon heard the game begin – so if this happens to you please wait. Secondly, the voice acting is poor. However, thankfully once you get out of the office there isn’t a lot of it and what little of it there is is bearable. That office seen, though, felt as though the voice actors didn’t particularly care for the job that they were doing. Not a good beginning. There are also grammatical errors in the English within the game but not to the point where you are dumbfounded at what is being said.

INFRA is one of the best new Indie games on Steam. It offers significant gameplay value at its current cost and is perfect for those of you who enjoy good adventure puzzle games with some horror thrown in for good measure. If you don’t buy it now because you’re waiting for the second part of the game to be released then you should at the very least put it on your wishlist.

I really love this game. Has a fair amount of puzzles, the puzzles are very nicely integrated both in the storyline and the enviroment, making it quite realistic.

20652201.review:
Игра очень непростая. С одной стороны, все понятно - мы, как инженер, должны осмотреть заброшенные объекты и сфотографировать поломки и оставшиеся документы. С другой - игра очень сырая и логические загадки далеко не логичные.  В добавок к этому - нет подсказок и направляющих. Игра просто оставляет вас один на один с ее миром и никак не вмешивается. 

В остальном, игра очень классная. Детально проработанные локации, хорошая графика. Даже удивлялся, насколько разработчики хорошо знают интерьер таких локаций. Все сделано на высшем уровне. Сюжет ни о чем конечно) Но опять же, это компенсируется визуальным миром) Это одна из тех игр, которую я купил сразу на старте, зная чего ожидать и очарованный ее оформлением:) Напоминает ту же Ethan Carter и ей подобные, только более скурпулезную в плане деталей и загадок.

Игра хоть и вышла, но активно развивается. Если на запуске и были жуткие баги (просто пропадал инвентарь), то это оперативно устраняется. Через месяц-другой можно ждать полноценный оптимизированный продукт, достойный внимания не только отдельных любителей жанра Приключение (Исследование, Симулятор ходьбы).

Пока этого достаточно на добрую четверку.

*INFRA - одна из тех игр, которые приятнее проходить со второго раза. В первый раз может показаться непонятной и оттолкнуть.

*После второй части, игра превратилась в эмулятор закрытых дверей и помещений. Все слишком банально и нудно. А некоторые тупняки, когда можно перепрыгнуть забор\перелезть через решетку, но по задумке нужно решать загадки и обходить все через всю карту - просто бесят. 

Первой частью я наслаждался: открытые красивые локации, интересные помещения.
Вторая часть меня раздражает: тупняки и канализации. 

Посмотрим, что будет в третьей, но вынужден поставить минус. Игра стала банальной.

20647309.review:
If you have an interest in urban exploration or have ever wondered what's behind those locked gates, inside those buildings full of blinkenlight panels and machinery that keep a city running, here is your chance to find out, and push some of the buttons along the way.

Visually gorgeous and dripping with atmosphere, INFRA is a solitary exploration / environmental puzzle game. A highly unique and enjoyable experience that really tickled the right spot for me with its attention to detail and atmosphere.

Some puzzles seem to be avoidable or optional and the reason for using the camera is not well explained. Several times I questioned my mental map of things to do, thinking about those locked doors or unpushed buttons that I'd promised to return to, then somehow managing to progress to the next section unable to return, wondering if I had maybe cheated the game. Perhaps this is an intentional design choice, I feel that the multiple paths and player choice elements could've been made clearer to avoid anxiety about fully exploring before moving on. Some kind of labelling/inventory system for keys/doors might've helped in that regard.

Voice acting is cheesily bad but thankfully sparse, and I did encounter some bugs (graphical glitches, had to reload saves to progress, achievements only earned if online in Steam).

Wishing the best success for Loiste Interactive and looking forward to Part 2 and any future projects.

20646110.review:
INFRA is possibly the best puzzle/exploration game I've played-and I've played them all. I've played through part 1 about five times now and I keep finding new secrets, puzzles and alternative routes.
Urban exploration or infrastructure enthusiasts will especially love it, but I'd recommend it for anyone who likes good settings or atmosphere.

A note on horror: INFRA gets its scares from the oppressive atmosphere of abandoned industrial settings, and its danger from industral hazards and accidents. There are no dogs leaping through windows or posessed pizza parlor animatronics to be found- no jump scares or bleeding walls, either. If you favor that kind of horror, best to look elsewhere- or better yet, try this game for a subtler flavor of fright!

20638337.review:
All the other reviews lay out the general pros and cons well, so I just wanted to reiterate one main point with this review.

Atmosphere. 

This game has it... lots of it. INFRA is on par with some of the greats in terms of atmosphere, like S.T.A.L.K.E.R, Metro, Half-Life, Bioshock, old school Silent Hill, or even the more recent Soma. The world is beautifully designed. The detail is incredible, and every building/area seems to be meticulously designed and unique in it's own way. Visually, the game is quite appealing, and impressive for a game running on Source. The environment strikes a nice balance; it is realistic and believable, yet remains imaginative throughout the story. 

Really, if you took away the poor voice acting and sometimes poorly written notes, you would be left with a game that doesn't look or feel Indie.

My main complaint is that it is far too short and ended quite abruptly, though the price reflects that. I very much look forward to the second part. 

Edit: Nearly 2 years later, and I finally got around to playing all three parts consecutively. It was hard to tell where the story was going to go after part 1, but I love the direction it went. 

I still adore the meticulous & realstic detail of the levels, with the final level really taking the cake. Overall, it's a game unlike no other, and while I understand it isn't for everybody, I wish it would get more credit. It's definitely the best under-the-radar game I've played, and a game I will never forget. Look forward to Loiste's future projects.

20632331.review:
Fantastic game. Currently I don't know if it's worth $15, but the developers are going to add further parts for no cost to those who own it, so it will be worth it in time.

Plot: The story feels a bit forced, but it is interesting, and fits very well with the concept of the game. It has a lot of potential for advancement, and is left on a cliffhanger that does work. I'm looking forward to the continuation with the updates.

Puzzles: The puzzles are Portal-style; built into the level, completing them is the only way to get through. There's a mix of physics puzzles, jumping puzzles, and others that incorporate many different concepts and features into them. Some are easy, some are very hard, but I was able to get through all of them except one without having to look on the discussion forums, and in that case, it was because the instructions were poorly worded. Here's a tip; remember to always look at EVERYTHING in the area. There are a few puzzles that I feel are unnecessarily hard, and one or two instances where the instructions themselves are unclear (water treatment plant...) but you can work past them, and the developers are very active on the forums answering questions if it comes to that.

Graphics: The game is gorgeous. There are some incredible locations, both outdoors and indoors. Some of the locations remind me of the coastal area in Half Life 2, but much more beautiful. So while the game produces plenty of great outdoor scenes, the indoor locations also do not fall to the tendency that games have to make their indoor locations boring and dark. The indoor locations feel varied but familiar, with new visuals every time.

Sounds: The sound design is pretty good, nothing to phone home about. There isn't much you can do with this kind of a game, but it feels atmospheric, which is about all is needed, I guess. Voice acting could use some work, particularly the main character, but it is far from game-breaking. The music is pretty average throughout, but there are a few points where [i]just[/i] the right piece starts playing at [i]just[/i] the right moment, creating a fantastic feeling.

Overall, if you like puzzles, I would recommend this game. The first part of the story took me about 9.3 hours to complete, with a pretty average amount of struggling, so with the updates, there will be enough content to make it worth it. If you've always wanted to be able to explore infrastructure (like me), this will be a blast. I can't vouch for its accuracy, but it feels realistic, and that's pretty much all I care about. I'm looking forward to what kind of new locations I'll get to explore in the next chapter.

20614629.review:
What a game. I usually have no interest in these puzzle games but INFRA is an exeption as I've followed the development for many years. And I also love games using the Source engine so of course I had to give it a go. 

I don't want to bore you with a long review where I point out every single thing that I liked or disliked so I'll keep it short. I also hope one of the developers read this review as I think that I make some interesting points.

[h1]So what is INFRA?[/h1]
INFRA is a game based around puzzle solving and exploration. It's based in modern times but you spend the majority of your time in abandoned buildings/areas. You encounter some puzzles along the way that you have to solve. Some are easy, some.. not so much. 


[h1]The good[/h1]
The level design is absolutely amazing. To see how much they managed to squeeze out of the good old Source engine is beyond what I could have imagined.
There's an interesting story to it which encourages you to progress and explore further.
There's a good amount of puzzles to keep you occupied throughout the game.
And then there's multiple approaches to pretty much everything.
The developers are showing great interest in the people who are playing it and are helping them out here on Steam!

[h1]The bad[/h1]
I'd like to mention first of all that I got stuck twice in my first playthrough due to crashes and bugs. Most of this has already been fixed though. 
The game is confusing at times. There's not much guidance for what you're doing so you keep asking yourself if this is the right thing. There are notes throughout the game that can help you solve the puzzles but you're not guaranteed to find them due to the multiple approaches. 
The multiple approaches makes you wonder if you've missed something. Would I have found a key to this door if I had gone the other way? Am I even supposed to go this way? 
The voice acting is not great. I don't mind the accent, it just gets annoying at times, especially the player's voice. He keeps pointing out the obvious. "Somebody should fix this","I'm pretty sure that's not meant to be like that", "A pack of spare batteries for the flashlight", "A pack of spare batteries for the camera", "I should have brought my other boots","Fascinating", "Interesting", and so on. You really don't need to point out the obvious, after all, I did make you pick up those batteries. 

Why not use the player's voice to help out the player? Something like "I wonder if I could get up there" or "Maybe if I can find a way to smash this". There's a bit of this towards the end of the game but I really would have liked it earlier on. (And it certainly could have helped me) I don't want it to give it away but maybe if you can tell that the player is struggling, help them out?

All in all, a very solid game and I definitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a bit of puzzle solving and/or exploration! If you want to avoid getting stuck because of bugs, wait a few weeks before buying and then I'm sure they've been fixed.

And a shoutout to one of the developers, Oskutin, for helping me out! ( I broke the game :D )

20596321.review:
Ok, here's the quick and dirty on INFRA: It's a first-person, non-combat puzzle game (much like Portal 2 or The Talos Principle). You'll follow an interesting and mysterious story, explore fantastic urban environments and solve environmental puzzles to progress.

The game has some flaws, which mainly come from a lack of time/money: the voice acting is dodgy at best, the character models are hilarious (and not in a good way) and even the written English texts have the occasional grammar error and misspelling (the devs are Finnish so that explains it somewhat).

But none of that matters. After the first level, voice acting is scarce and there's no hideous characters models to look at, only the amazing environments (look at those screenshots!).
If you like exploring atmospheric worlds and solve clever and logical puzzles don't even think twice. Buy it.

THE DREADED "VALUE" QUESTION:

It's a known fact that most indie games nowadays don't offer much in terms of length and sometimes ask a hefty price. INFRA is the exact opposite. The game costs just 15€ and the first part alone can last you over 10 hours. The second part is coming later this year and it'll be FREE if you already own part 1. That's a lot of high-quality gaming for just 15€ and more devs should follow this example.
